name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Before we continue the debates, we move on to today's first voting period. We will then vote on the dossiers as indicated on the agenda and, before we begin, rapporteur Tomáš Zdechovský asked to speak before the 2018 discharge period.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that the Treaty of Lisbon implies one important role for the European Parliament, and that is to control the European Union's budget. And we cannot accept that they are the institutions of the European Union, which take the European Union budget as a gift, as something that comes to them every year and that they think that they can behave the way they do.  This year, with the Committee on Budgetary Control, we have decided unequivocally that we do not support discharge by the two institutions. One is traditionally the European Council and the Council, where, unfortunately, despite enormous efforts, no consensus has been found on how the clearance of accounts procedure is to be carried out. The second institution is the European Economic and Social Committee, which has clearly been unable to answer our questions when communicating with us in its various misconduct and has not been able to take measures that would give us confidence that it is capable of properly protecting the interests of European citizens.  Ladies and gentlemen, that's why I took the floor today. There is a need to send out a clear signal that we will not tolerate anyone in the European Parliament or in the European institutions who is not besading properly towards European funds, and I ask you to vote unequivocally in support of our proposal. Thank you, have a nice day, a happy mind and most importantly, I wish you all health!

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The voting period runs from 9:15 a.m. to 10:30 a.m.  Voting is taken according to the same procedure used above.  All votes will be carried out by roll call vote. name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: I would like to inform you that in this debate there will be no catch-the-eye procedures or blue card questions, and that invocations from the Rules of Procedure are accepted. In addition, distance interventions are made for by member states' liaison offices.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has  There is a time for discussion. There is also a right time for compromise, and there is also a right time for decisions. Right, the reform has been discussed for a long time. You could say that the reform was introduced by Phil Hogan in 2018. For information to our younger colleagues, that was our then Commissioner for Agriculture. Mrs Herranz accompanied the dossier until the election, and after the 2019 election, we started a wide-ranging debate. We wanted to reach a major compromise with our colleague from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Energy, but unfortunately the chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs cancelled these discussions. Now there is a package on the table, and honestly, I would have done the reform very differently. This is the same for my colleague, Mrs Noichl, Mr Lavlavsek, Häusling, Bert-Jan Ruissen and all the other rapporteurs. Everyone had their own ideas and would do much, much better. Of course, we need to formulate group positions, but we are here above all to find compromises. That requires courage. Meckering is always easier than helping, and that is why I would ask all the political groups to be courageous and agree to the compromise. On the substance, 30% are reserved for the so-called eco-schemes, 35% of the second pillar for environmental and climate measures. Flexibility between the two pillars is given for environmentally relevant measures. 30% of the investment is earmarked for investment in climate and environmental measures. We have increased conditionality, legumes in crop rotation, definitions of water protection margins, the land should be green all year round, every farmer must keep 5% of his agricultural area free of fertilisers and plant protection products. At Member State level, by the way, this figure should be 10%, and we have a completely new style. It is to be changed from a previously action-oriented model to a goal-oriented model, and this creates the necessary freedom for the Member States if the target is achieved. That is why we are once again appealing to all Members who are perhaps dissatisfied in detail: the really important thing will then be this national strategic plan, and there we must quite simply help to ensure that the Member States also seize the opportunity and that there is less bureaucracy for European farmers. That is why we are once again appealing – including to all the critics – to give the reform a chance in the interests of the environment, in the interests of climate protection, and above all in the interests of European farmers. They need planning certainty. We have decided on a two-year transition period to put this new Deliver model into practice.  This model must not only be adopted, it must not only be coordinated with Brussels, it must also be understood by practice. Therefore, once again, I would ask all members of Parliament to take part in finding a compromise, do not stand aside and give reform to European agriculture!

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. After two years of intensive work, we are finally coming to a vote on the common agricultural policy. We must take a clear position in this vote and refer to the ten million farmers we have within Europe. They need a future perspective and planning security.  Unfortunately, there has been and is a lot of negative sentiment about what farmers should do for society and what society's performance is worth. What is clear is that we need our farming families and strong economic areas in all regions of Europe – I stress farming families. 8.5 million holdings are smaller than seventeen hectares. These farmers rely on us and provide us with the highest quality food every day.  It is precisely in the period of the Corona pandemic that the population – especially in the wealthy Member States – has probably been thinking about security of supply for the first time in a long time. We are now setting a practical and workable framework for the common agricultural policy, and it needs pragmatic and sensible approaches and must not be seen as ideologically driven in the management of agriculture and food. The CAP has been an important brace of our region for decades and an important brace within Europe. 'Unity in diversity' is our motto and this is now also reflected in this new future common agricultural policy. For me, in my report, there were four important issues and large blocs: what should the future agricultural policy look like? Firstly, the people in the regions know best how to shape the framework in the national strategic plans. That is why the approach is right to enshrine more flexibility for the Member States and to abolish the 'one size fits all' principle. This means that agriculture and forestry as a profession and the rural population must be actively involved in the preparation of national strategic plans in European countries.  Secondly, to shift more responsibility to the Member States, but at the same time to maintain a genuine common agricultural policy, is an important step forward for me. The consistent implementation of the single audit principle – that is, the elimination of double auditing – relieves the burden on the Member States and thus also on farmers. At the same time, reporting actual results on the basis of europe-wide key figures results in a fair and transparent implementation of the objectives of the CAP.  Thirdly, our farmers are already doing a great deal to promote biodiversity, soil protection and water protection and climate protection in addition to the supply of food. This requires feasible, regionally tailored concepts plus training and further education with the latest scientific status. This is the great opportunity of the supply model and the eco-schemes and the common opportunity to create incentives to reward farmers who implement the best possible economic methods on their farms in their regions. In Bavaria, one in three hectares is in environmental programmes – and this must not be jeopardised in the second pillar.  Fourthly, in some Member States, the implementation and control of EU funding is difficult, either due to weak administrative structures or a lack of transparency. This complaint mechanism, which we are introducing for farmers, is an important step towards this.  I believe that the report I have presented on funding, administration and control will enable us to respond adequately to the challenges in society. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for the constructive open dialogue, and I continue to hope for your support.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, there is much to be said about the way this reform of the common agricultural policy is presented, but I will of course only present and address the report for which I am responsible, which is the report on the common organisation of markets. The common organisation of the markets: these three words have never been so topical. The health crisis we are experiencing is a reminder, if needed, that the invisible hand of the market does not exist, Mr President, that markets cannot self-regulate, that all this is a decoy and that the regulation or regulations are there to improve the functioning of markets. Agricultural markets are structurally unstable, that is a fact. We must ensure a fairer and more stable income for our farmers in order to support them in the future green transition, and the common organisation of markets is there above all to better manage crises. We need to be effective. Yes, the markets are unstable: it is a fact, but it is not inevitable. It is for this reason, Commissioner, that we must put the Commission at the centre of the scheme. It is for this reason that the Commission must remain the guarantor of market integrity in the face of crises, that it must fully play its role as sector regulator - and this is our first proposal: sectoral regulator in agriculture. Like any management authority, it must establish an action strategy within a performance framework, based on monitoring indicators and results. It must therefore be assessed every year and be accountable to Parliament and the Council. In order for the Commission to play its role effectively as sector regulator, we propose to create a single European observatory for agricultural markets, which will have to collect more information, not just on milk and sugar, but on all sectors - this is the novelty. It should improve transparency and thus trigger early warnings in order to put in place appropriate management tools: assistance to private storage of course, public storage as a last resort, voluntary withdrawals that have been proposed unanimously by the groups involved. But also, Mr President, Commissioner, we are going to propose with my group - and I thank my President Iratxe Garcia Pérez - the mandatory withdrawal. The idea is to allow the Commission to decide on mandatory withdrawal in the event of a serious crisis. I will call on you to vote en masse on this amendment, because it will regulate production in the event of a serious crisis. By your vote, ladies and gentlemen, you will also be able to secure organic producers. If we are to reach 25% of the area in organic farming by 2030, we need to secure farmers and guarantee them a price level so that they can make their transition. That is what we are proposing in Amendment 274, also tabled by my group. In the event of a market crisis, the European Union will have to pay for the differential between the price of the organic product and the price of the product from conventional agriculture. Among other measures, it is imperative that import quotas for favourable duty products respect social and environmental conditions. Imported products that do not meet EU production standards will be banned outright. As for viticulture, as you know, this sector is hard hit by the health crisis: it had to be given opportunities. We also propose the extension of planting permits until 2050 and a simplification of the procedure to modify the specifications of protected appellations of origin. And to allow the sector to adapt to the evolution of consumption, we will allow wines below 8.5 degrees to be wines, so that this fringe of the market does not escape the sector of viticulture. This is an important issue. Finally, to enable consumers to fully understand what they are ingesting, particularly with regard to viticulture products, as for solid foods, we will propose a labeling indicating the calories and what is in the wine bottle, that is, the list of ingredients, either on the bottle or in a dematerialized way. This is also the case with the future of the wine industry, and I wanted to highlight that. Another step forward seems important to me: all products under protected origin will be able to collectively adapt their production to demand. What is possible today for wine, cheese and ham only can now be applied to all sectors. If I take the example of the county in France, we see how this sector can regulate production since it controls the whole sector from the upstream to the downstream, which is also important to do with force. Finally, we propose to improve the functioning of producer organisations and inter-professional organisations, and to strengthen them. This is imperative so that farmers can seek more value. It is through more collective action, not individualism and opportunism, that they will do better tomorrow. I would also like to say a few words about the name of meats. Commissioner, there is a gap in European legislation on this issue. It is necessary to properly inform the consumer, but also to allow vegetable proteins to develop as well as animal proteins. We will therefore have to complete the European legislation. That is the purpose of Amendment 275, which deals with section 78, and that we are proposing to you, again, with my group. It is important to maintain equity between plant and animal proteins. In conclusion, I would like, Mr President, Commissioner, to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and all the teams who participated in our work and have done an excellent job and, thus, the development of a report which will undoubtedly give economic prospects for the future of European agriculture.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, the current pandemic has made it clear to us that the CAP is important in ensuring food security in Europe. At the same time, agriculture as an economic sector must contribute, as far as possible, to the common struggles that are the struggles against climate change, for better protection of our water reserves and against the loss of biodiversity. But also the very survival of our farmers must be guaranteed, because without farmers, we will not be able to fight climate change or produce sufficient healthy food. As rapporteur on strategic plans in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security, I thank all the colleagues who have contributed constructively to the process because we have results: buffer zones along rivers and the protection of permanent grasslands to name a few.  However, I denounce the irresponsible behaviour of those who have torpedoed the joint work between the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security and the Committee on Agriculture and Sustainable Development. We could have done better and faster in the interests of the environment and our farmers.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I’d like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Jahr, Ms Müller and Mr Andrieu, for their hard work in recent months to reach a compromise with the shadow rapporteurs and the political groups on the three common agricultural policy (CAP) legislative proposals. We are at a crucial moment in the process towards the new common agricultural policy. Both the Council, negotiating the general approach at this very moment in Luxembourg, and the European Parliament here in Brussels are finalising their respective mandates and preparing to enter the decisive stage of trilogues.  It is important for our farmers and our farming community to have clarity on the legal framework for the years to come. We need a strong common agricultural policy to ensure that European agriculture can continue to provide economic, environmental and social benefits for our farmers and citizens in the future. This includes the delivery of stronger environmental and climate ambitions, as set out in the Green Deal and the farm to fork strategy.  I welcome the fact that many honourable Members agree with this basic orientation for the future common agricultural policy. However, I note that some amendments do not share our ambition for a greener and fairer CAP. Let me briefly turn now to the individual proposals to mention a few key points about the Strategic Plan Regulation. If we want to achieve the objectives of the European Green Deal, it is essential that the key elements of its green architecture are maintained or further strengthened in the future CAP. This is especially essential if we want the CAP to contribute in a credible manner with 40% of its spending to the 30% overall climate objective of the EU budget.  Let me now highlight the main building blocks of our green architecture and where we stand in this respect. Regarding conditionality, the foundation of the future environmental ambition comes from the proposed enhanced conditionality, including the good agricultural and environmental conditions (GAEC) applicable to all farmers as a condition for receiving full direct payment. Strong GAECs are essential for reaching the climate and environmental goals established by the European Green Deal. This is particularly true for GAEC 9, which is key to the success of the biodiversity strategy. The proposal to reduce the scope of this GAEC to arable land only will not be sufficient to reach our targets. While I agree that the problem may be more acute on arable land, such an approach is counterproductive in halting the loss of biodiversity because other types of agricultural land should also contribute to the biodiversity targets. Allowing farmers to fulfil their obligation with respect to biodiversity by simply not spraying pesticides and fertiliser on 5% of their arable land, regardless of the crops, would be a step backwards compared with the current situation. This would not contribute to our biodiversity strategy. Regarding the eco-schemes, these are key and they are designed to make a difference and incentivise farmers to maintain and adopt the practices necessary for the green transition. The Commission strongly supports an ambitious and credible ring-fencing of eco-schemes and welcomes the amendment in this respect. The Commission is, at the same time, fully aware of the risk that some funding could be left unspent if farmers do not sign up to these measures in sufficient numbers, especially in the first years. We share these concerns and are ready to explore possible solutions, such as making ring-fencing in Pillar 1 more flexible or taking on board higher efforts made under Pillar 2 on the environmental objectives. Any flexibility must be compatible with the high environmental and climate ambition and the 40% spending target to which I referred previously.  In that sense, when considering eco-schemes, let’s keep in mind that it is not only about ambitious budget allocations. The quality of eco-schemes is equally essential to delivering our environmental and climate ambition.  During my recent exchange with the members of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI), we discussed a non-exhaustive list of possible eco-schemes. We are ready to continue working with the co-legislator in this area, while acknowledging that Member States should be able to design eco-schemes best adapted to their specific needs and circumstances.  Another layer in our environmental ambition concerns the ring-fencing of 30% of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) budget for agro-environmental measures. We now see attempts to include payments to areas with natural constraints (ANCs) and with limited environmental contribution, as shown by recent evaluations, in this ring-fencing. This is not credible. The European Court of Auditors has rightly criticised this. We are aware of this. This would be backsliding from the current situation where at EU level we are spending 35% on the environment and climate under the Agricultural Fund for Rural Development without ANC payments. If the finally proposed ring-fencing of 35% were to include 40% of ANC payments, this would be a step backwards compared with today. We have to be serious about the new environmental ambition of the CAP and, therefore, we are determined to count under the ring-fencing only payments for farmers or other beneficiaries who do more for the environment than simply respecting baseline obligations. This is not the case of ANC payments.  Please allow me to make one final comment on the Strategic Plan Regulation and the performance review. To ensure the CAP delivers on its core objectives and the Green Deal objectives, we need the right performance indicators and a regular review. If it is to have a credible mechanism to defend publicly the added value of the CAP, the Commission needs the means to adequately monitor and, if necessary, take action against those Member States lagging behind. Ideally, we need a yearly review covering all results indicators included in the CAP plan. A strong monitoring system and the means to steer implementation will allow the Commission to report regularly and comprehensively to the European Parliament, ensuring transparency and enabling public scrutiny.  Regarding the new delivery model and the horizontal regulation proposed by Ms Müller, I note that the Commission proposal for the new common agricultural policy is based on the premise that it is working well. There is continuity from the current period in the structure and role of the governance bodies. The Commission proposal clearly states that the Member States must deliver on performance and have a robust governance system in place, such as paying agencies as part of the integrated administration and control system and the land parcel identification system. This will ensure sound financial management. Member States will check eligibility at beneficiary level. This does not mean that there will be no controls in the future. Moreover, the Commission can take appropriate measures if national control systems are not operational. We will still have a robust assurance model. However, detailed eligibility rules set at the level of the Union requirements would create a system where Member States would have to report on compliance on top of performance and the Commission would have to audit the detailed rules. This two-layer system – compliance and performance-based – would entail an unbearable administrative burden for the Member States. A two-layer system, together with the amendments proposed on the performance review and the performance clearance, may prevent the Member States from timely delivery on performance. Finally, on the Common Market Organisation (CMO) Regulation and Mr Andrieu’s report on the proposal, in its 2018 proposal, the Commission maintained the architecture and main features of the current CMO. It is my firm conviction that we should avoid reverting to the old CAP with permanent intervention in markets with automatic triggers of crisis measures that would blow market signals and annihilate the market orientation given to the policy since the 1990s. Market intervention instruments have been successfully triggered in a flexible and timely manner in previous years, together with the possibility for the Commission to adopt exceptional measures whenever needed. Introducing new compulsory procedural steps would weaken and slow down the ability of the European Union to respond to any agricultural market crises. Exceptional measures should respect the same principles of market orientation, avoiding the reintroduction of production quotas.  In relation to the wine package, we are open to discuss some of the amendments, but the duration of our current vine-planting authorisation scheme, introduced in 2016, should not be changed as it would be premature to extract any conclusions today. The regime is due to be reassessed in 2023. Panie Przewodniczący! Jeszcze raz dziękuję za wspólną pracę, za konstruktywną współpracę. Jestem przekonany, że tworzymy reformę, która uczyni rolnictwo europejskie bardziej przyjaznym dla środowiska, dla klimatu, dla dobrostanu zwierząt, ale również reformę, która uczyni rolnictwo europejskie bardziej odpornym na kryzysy. Reformę, która wzmocni bezpieczeństwo ekonomiczne naszych rolników i która zapewni bezpieczeństwo żywnościowe dla naszych obywateli teraz i w przyszłości.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – Honourable rapporteurs, all three, sincere thanks for your work over the last year, year and a half, two. It was huge. Dear colleagues, it is our great responsibility to adopt such a reform of the common agricultural policy, which will enable European farmers to continue to provide healthy, quality and affordable food for Europeans. We must provide farmers with decent income for their work and an equivalent position in the food chain.  We must further support small farms that are abandoning farming very quickly. The average age of European farmers is over 57 years, so I welcome the measures that support young takers. However, we must not forget the social situation of those who surrender the farm.  I support measures that promote knowledge transfer, digitisation of agricultural production and measures in support of the concept of smart villages. These are measures that will enable the settlement of Europe's rural areas.  Farmers have been the ones we should thank for the landscape and environmental protection.  In the future, more funding is foreseen under the green architecture of the common agricultural policy, for protecting the environment and combating climate change, the consequences of which are first felt by farmers.  In any case, the basic function of agriculture remains to produce enough food for farmers to have a decent income, and we must therefore support farmers who actually produce food through basic payment and production-linked payments.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, we have made cohesion and ecology the watchwords of the economic recovery of the new Green Pact for Europe and the new budgetary framework. We must ensure that the objectives are consistent in Community policies and that is precisely what we expect from the common agricultural policy.  For our Committee on Regional Development, reducing territorial divides is an obsession. We believe that the common agricultural policy can contribute to the development of rural, forestry and agricultural areas and that this requires the maintenance of populations in rural areas, as well as sustainable incomes for farmers. Our REGI committee also calls for the future CAP not to penalise ultra-peripheral regions and that is why our report rejects the cuts proposed by the European Commission and I would like to thank, on behalf of our whole committee, the Committee on Agriculture and Sustainable Development, as well as rapporteur Éric Andrieu for maintaining their firm and uncompromising position in this direction.  We are now waiting, Commissioner, for the Council, which is meeting today, to return to a position of reason and validate the European Parliament's position for the maintenance of the POSEI budget. In conclusion, I call on all colleagues to stand firm and not give in to this battle.

name: Anne SANDER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, the common agricultural policy allows an entire profession to carry out the noblest of tasks: to ensure a food supply of affordable and quality products for our citizens, but also to participate in the development of our rural areas. As a member of the EPP Group's negotiating team on this reform, I know how difficult and sometimes frustrating the negotiation process has been in recent months. Nevertheless, an agreement was reached. The gradual integration of environmental and climate issues into the common agricultural policy is one of the hallblys of its evolution. Nevertheless, let us not give in to the excess in this area by promoting political totems and big figures outside of any concrete reality. I prefer to rely on the ground and the truth is that farmers have not waited for us to engage in the transition of their practices and we must support them through incitement rather than coercion, through accompaniment rather than through sanctions. While the CAP's environmental and climate ambition is strengthened by this agreement, it also ensures a balance between these objectives and income support for farmers and the economic development of the sectors. Ladies and gentlemen, we have fought in recent months to ensure that the common agricultural policy remains a tool for agricultural economics, as this policy is essential to support European sectors in their development, their structuring but also to help them cope with the globalisation of trade. We have introduced new operational programmes, revised the rules on tools for cooperation between farmers, secured the missions of inter-professionals in relation to the application of competition law, strengthened supply management tools for quality products and, finally, permanently extended the system of planting permits until 2050.  Similarly, we have fought to reform the crisis reserve to make it more operational and to set up a European observatory to improve market transparency and enable the Union to intervene quickly in the event of a major crisis. Finally, an ecological barrier is introduced through the ban on entry into the European market of products that do not comply with our health and environmental standards. Colleagues, one of the main challenges of the reform is also the maintenance of the common character of the common agricultural policy. If the CAP is to be flexible in order to adapt to the realities of European territories, it is essential to maintain a strong common ground, otherwise we will go towards 27 divergent European agricultural policies and we will not be able to guarantee equal treatment between farmers.  Parliament has also committed itself against this deadly trend of the European idea. Colleagues, together despite our differences, let us defend this common ambition.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, in mid-March Europe stopped. They closed the companies, closed the offices, closed the schools. Europe stopped, but we were able, through the impetus of work and the commitment of our primary sector, our farmers and farmers, our farmers and livestock farmers, to ensure food security, to ensure food for our families. Undoubtedly this has been an essential moment to see the importance of the debate that brings us here today, that of a new reform of the common agricultural policy that advances the objective that we have clear from the European institutions: a more environmentally sustainable CAP, more socially sustainable, that is able to ensure food security so as not to depend on outside production and , too, that it is able to guarantee living wages to farmers and farmers. We have been trying for several decades to transform our agriculture to be more in line with our environmental policies and also to ensure that products have a higher quality and safety, with new traceability systems. With each reform we delve into these objectives, but, as we have said, we must try to adapt them to the great diversity that we have in Europe. This text puts environmental architecture at the heart of the reform. The first key is that direct payments will be subject to enhanced conditionality with a clear environmental seal. What until now was optional now becomes the norm. 30% of the pillar will first be reserved for new echoesquemas, a series of new interventions. This will take environmental ambition to unprecedented levels in terms of the budget: 30% in the first pillar of direct aid. In addition, we want to ensure at least 35% in rural development. We don't want it to be an environmental-only policy, we also want it to have a social dimension, and for that it is necessary to ensure that jobs are of quality and that there is a generational renewal. It is necessary to put an end to the generational stopper that exists on farms right now, and therefore the incorporation of young people is essential.  But let us not forget also the importance of women. Our rural environment is totally masculinized. We lose women in rural areas, and when a village loses the last woman living in that town, it's about to disappear. It is therefore essential that we incorporate the gender dimension so that there are policies aimed at women. 95% are small family businesses, and in each area of the European Union they face diverse challenges. That is why national plans must also be adapted to the regional realities we have in Europe at the moment. Agriculture in the European Union is the most diversified in the world, and we are adapting. The CAP is a key pillar of the European Green Pact. The CAP together with the farm-to-table strategy and biodiversity strategy must make our food industry healthier, fairer and more environmentally friendly. And that is why we will continue to work to provide the Union with a legislative framework that goes beyond this CAP, because we need to adapt it to a new reality. For all of them and for all of them, we'll keep working.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, farmers should be much less dependent on direct income support. Direct income support is not a measure that structurally improves farmers' competitiveness. Instead, farmers should be given much more opportunity to earn their income from the market. I am therefore also pleased that a proposal of mine has been included in the final compromise text of the European Parliament. I am calling for European competition rules to leave more room for agricultural sustainability initiatives. Of course, agreements in the chain should not lead to prices getting high. This is not in the interests of the consumer, but it is in the interests of the consumer that the products are produced more sustainably. So I believe that the European Competition Authority should also look at this and leave more room in the chain to reach agreements on sustainability, and that the additional costs incurred for a better environment, better animal welfare and a better climate can actually be passed on in the price. A second aspect is greening policy within the common agricultural policy. The European Court of Auditors has been rather critical of this not working. I agree with that and I see that several things need to be adapted. At the moment, generic measures from Brussels are sending farmers to work more sustainably. Only, the differences in Europe are large: in Finland it is snowing at the moment and in Athens it is beautiful weather. The local conditions are not sufficiently considered. And perhaps a bigger problem is that it is only being looked at whether the measures from Brussels have actually been implemented by the farmer and that the effects of these measures on the farm have not been looked at at all.  So we have to do it the other way around. We need to start steering on performance. We need to steer on the results that the individual companies achieve. And please also use the knowledge of the farmer. Because he knows exactly what is happening on his farm in the local conditions.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the new common agricultural policy is certainly one of the most important reforms of the whole parliamentary term. The CAP is one of the few European programmes that has worked in recent years and has brought real money to our companies and territories.  I, who have been able to participate in the drafting of this CAP, can say that there have been positive aspects in this reform, but also negative aspects. Well what was done, but much more could have been done. Much more could have been done to cut red tape, which is the first real major problem facing our farmers every day; Much more could have been done not to put the weight of the environmental measures wanted by the European Commission on the shoulders of farmers. It is often forgotten in Brussels that the first guardians of the environment are precisely farmers and that we need agriculture that is environmentally sustainable, but above all economically sustainable. More could be done to defend PDO and PGI products and more could be done in the fight against unfair competition that steals 100 billion euros a year from Made in Italy.  The new CAP also puts new challenges on the table, such as the designation of meat that affects millions of farmers and consumers. There is no meat without meat. Synthetic meat, the one made in the laboratory, inside which there is not a single milligram of meat cannot be called meat. Our farmers and consumers must be protected, not cheated in order to please the interests of some multinationals.  We all know that the real game on the CAP is the one linked to the European budget. The future CAP will be positive or negative depending on how much money will be allocated to agriculture in the 2021-2027 budget and on this point there is still total darkness. But one thing must be clear to everyone, as we have already done in recent months, and we are ready to fight to reject any proposal for cuts in the CAP. Italian farmers must not be deprived of a euro. On this we will fight to the end, together with our farmers, because the lives of thousands of companies are at stake and we must all protect them, because, as the Coronavirus emergency has shown, a country without agriculture is a country that has no future.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which What the grand coalition is putting on the table here does not deserve the name 'reform'. This is a 'continuing like this' in the common agricultural policy.  We have had a chaotic process with the shadow rapporteurs, and we have a vote today which is simply a scandal. No split votes, everything is only voted on, so to speak, if the grand coalition wants it, and we simply do not have the floor with amendments. This is a scandal. In the shadow of the Corona crisis, we now want to wave through something that really does not deserve the name 'reform'. What annoys me is that everyone here is talking about 30% eco-schemes. Talk about the fact that it is now to be stipulated that 60% of payments are still direct payments, per area! The big farmers benefit from this, but the small farmers we need do not benefit from it. This is where Mr Babi' and Mr Orban can rejoice, and 80% of the money still goes to 20% of the companies. That will remain the case, so this is not a reform!  To me, I have to say honestly that the Socialists are the fallers of the year. We have always worked well together in the central meetings, but now they are joining the EPP. I am only surprised by this, they have to explain it. Yesterday we received a report from the Environment Agency which presents very dramatic figures. 81% of natural areas are at risk, 63% of animal species are at risk, and we are pretending that we can continue with this agricultural policy. What about the farm-to-fork strategy that is not in the template? What about the biodiversity strategy that is not in it?  They do without specific goals, as in the farm-to-fork strategy. 50% fewer pesticides, 50% fewer antibiotics, less fertilisers, but also less cheap soya imports, water consumption, more protein production in Europe. We need 10% of the area that guarantees biodiversity. None of this is in the proposals at all. Instead, at the eco-schemes, you're talking about precision farming, a farmer who squirts more accurately doesn't automatically squirt less! So, the whole thing is a laughing stock, if you look at what is being proposed now. What surprises me, Commissioner, is that you remain so calm throughout the story. With this 'reform', the Commission will not be able to make the Green Deal or achieve its climate targets. That will not happen. That is why, Commissioner, you are putting forward a new proposal, and you can do so at any time. Perhaps we can save something else, but for that we need the Commission.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the challenges we face in the common agricultural policy are large and diverse: ensuring adequate healthy and safe food, for healthy economic businesses and with sufficient attention to nature and the environment on and around businesses. The package of strategic plans before us today does disappoint in this respect. Not only because it is only submitted by three groups, but also because of the thinking in these plans. It is still too much assumed that everything must be arranged centrally from Brussels, with all the consequences for the regulatory burden. You can see it very clearly in the basic premium, which demands even more, whereas the challenges of the future require entrepreneurship and therefore freedom for the entrepreneur to make his own choices. Fortunately, the eco-scheme has succeeded in providing a piece of customization. We also find it very difficult to provide sufficient financial compensation. As has been said, higher requirements are being placed on the basic premium, but at the same time it is going down by 30% or more. That's not fair, of course. The farmer is also required to take 10 % of his land out of production, whereas because of the system chosen, he can only be compensated financially for half of it. That too is, of course, very debatable. We need a policy that leaves room for innovative power and contributes to a fair price. In doing so, it is crucial that the agricultural budget is maintained in the interests of a strong and sustainable agricultural sector, which is ultimately in the interests of all of us.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this is a massively important debate. It is a massively important reform of the common agricultural policy (CAP). It will decide how our food is produced, how our land is managed, how our environment is protected or indeed destroyed. My message to the EPP, the S&D and the Renew Group is that if you are so sure that what you propose is good then leave it open to democratic scrutiny. However, the use of Rule 183 makes that impossible and you know that. The chairman of the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) Committee tells us that we torpedoed the process. This is totally untrue. I have tried to make this work, but the reality is that the EPP clearly don’t want it to work. They deliberately destroyed the process in the same way as a spoilt rich kid calls halt to a game of football because they own the ball and they can. I did not sign the rejection amendment because I had some little bit of faith in those that I have worked with for the last few years. Not anymore. I had some hope that her amendments would make the CAP reform in some way meaningful. Amendments that would have really ringfenced money for the environment. Amendments that would have excluded areas that have nothing to do with the environment. Amendments that would have led to more money for the family farm. Amendments that would have recognised the reality that without a just transition, there will be no transition at all. However, now I am forced to vote for Amendment 1147 to send back the CAP to the Commission in order for them to come up with a green deal that is compatible with what they should be doing. We have time to do this correctly. We have the two-year transition period where we can come up with a common agricultural policy that works for farmers, for consumers and for the planet. We have the evidence from the European Court of Auditors. They are not biased. They just follow the evidence. They are telling us that we must change our ways. They are telling us that what we have been doing is not working, and to ignore them is to throw insult at the people of the European Union, and we shouldn’t do this. We should reject this proposal.

name: Dino GIARRUSSO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are going to vote on the reform of the common agricultural policy and we will be able to make history, because nothing like agriculture can restart the Europe torn apart by Covid, can create development and work, improve the environment and promote our excellence.  Unfortunately, Parliament should dare more, overcome the reluctance of some Member States that are always conservative in the Council when it comes to greening, stability, sustainability and innovation. No cuts, clear position on eco-schemes with mandatory adequate percentage. We need more ambition on intensive farming and animal welfare, including organic farming and precision agriculture; accelerate digitalization so as to reduce emissions, increasing the quality of products and working for an honest labeling system that promotes all this, abandoning the disastrous Nutri-Score and respecting Made in, Made in Italy in particular. We need to act against the caporalato intelligently. The farmer and the worker must have the same interest in a regular agreement, with advantages for those who behave well by including social conditionality. Payments should therefore be cut to those who do not respect the workers. The new CAP must serve to change for the better and not to perpetuate social and cultural brakes that limit the take-off of our agriculture. I am therefore pleased with the extension of the right of planting for vines and the inclusion of hemp in the standard markets, but I hope that the standard will reach 0.5 % and that all Member States from Italy will be obliged by European regulations to break the cultural prejudice against this sector, which will bring enormous environmental, social, economic and cultural benefits, including against mafias. It is a battle that must be won together, on which we will not give up a millimetre.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Colleagues, the common agricultural policy is a royal policy of the European Union, and with this vote these days we are giving this policy a basic orientation for this decade. My group will support the compromises negotiated. We believe they are moving in the right direction.  We need a balanced European agricultural policy. We need a balance between a policy that – yes – looks at sustainability, which looks at climate change, but which also looks at the needs for citizens' daily food. And, Commissioner, this food security is also important, and that is something you should have in mind as the responsible Commissioner for Agriculture.  I believe that it is precisely the sad moments of the COVID-19 crisis that have shown us how important it is to take care of ourselves. And I don't want us to be on the same terms as with the protective masks and ventilators, where we had to import every junk out of the world and they were then bought away from us in front of our noses.  But we also need agriculture that looks at the diverse consumer needs and has the needs in mind – good if there is more demand for organic goods, for local production, for short supply chains. But we must also feed those who cannot afford the delicatessen every day in a safe and dignified way – there are also those in Europe. In any case, I do not want European agriculture producing for the top ten thousand, and those who have to look at the purse when they go to the supermarket will then get cheap junk from abroad.  We should not forget one thing: at the end of the day, we are talking about the ten million or so farmers in Europe. Only if our policy also helps them to get an income will they continue to exist and then there will continue to be young people in agriculture. Being a farmer is not a hobby, as is sometimes portrayed here, it is a profession. And only if we create the conditions with which they can live for all farmers, even in the more difficult situations – in the mountains – will they continue to find young successors.  I hope that this week we will set a good foundation stone for farmers, for young farmers, for consumers and for the environment in Europe.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. First of all, I would like to protest strongly that the votes of the CAP have been brought forward from Wednesday to Tuesday. This is an unagreed step, and another agenda was adopted on Monday.  This administrative action has caused very, very great unrest in Parliament. It has rightly been attacked, many citizens are upset, and NGOs and members of the press believe that cheating is taking place here. You read, it's tactics, you read, it's a self-aggrandism, and I would like to say once again, as shadow rapporteur for the S&D: this decision must be reversed immediately, the old agenda must be adhered to.  But let me now move on to the substance: a long, very complicated way of voting towards the CAP is behind us. First of all, I would like to address my speech to Mrs Ursula von der Leyen. Ursula von der Leyen did not perform her duty of care. It has tacitly accepted that, although it has proclaimed the Green Deal, an old proposal in the Agriculture Commission remained on the table. It has tacitly accepted that there is no proper link to the Green Deal, farm-to-fork or biodiversity strategy. It has remained silent, although we have said time and again in many places that we need a new reform package. It has been negligent of her to do nothing, just to remain silent and not to act. Now we have the situation we are facing: is this old draft reform even green-deal-capable, can we even change it so that it fits into the world now? I think that is really a very, very difficult question. We have tried - it is our job as A Parliament to try to get the best out of it." We have tried to improve this really bad draft by Mr Hogan. We have many amendments from ENVI, and although I work in the Committee on Agriculture and Consumer Development, I hope that all the amendments from ENVI will then really be adopted and accepted in Parliament. We absolutely need 30% eco-schemes – that is the least for me. It is essential that we have clear objectives for the CAP. It is essential that we have a clear link with the farm-to-fork, biodiversity strategy and the Paris Agreement. We absolutely need good green architecture, we need good red architecture, social architecture in agriculture. We must make it clear that capping is a matter of justice. Capting means justice, and we need a clear anchoring of our agricultural policy in the region. The old proposal as it stands here still has a mathematical climate protection in it. We have managed to wipe this area absolutely off the table, we cannot say that there is a computational climate protection, we automatically count the area figures at 40%. And here I am grateful to my group, the S&D Group, which has said from the outset that there will be no computational climate protection with us, but only a real, a truly science-based climate protection. I would also like to say a few words to Mrs Klöckner: Mrs Klöckner, you in the Council, if you dare to water down this result here from Parliament, then you will sin against the next generation. If you dare to talk about voluntary eco-schemes, if you dare to talk about climate money ending up with bis payments, then you are sining. Under no circumstances must they greenwash the results of Parliament's vote, whatever the outcome. This is not allowed.  I would like to thank my colleagues in Parliament for working so well together, and I would like to thank the NGO groups that are on the streets. Because pressure from the road is important, important, important!

name: Martin HLAVÁČEK
text: – Mr President, for the third year running, the countryside, farmers, food farmers and citizens have been waiting for our ability to agree on the direction of the common agricultural policy and on a vision for our countryside. We shouldn't wait any longer. Citizens do not understand why we are not able to come to an agreement after all this time, especially in these very difficult times. Those who do not want to make a deal seriously risk supporting the European project and helping those who want to subvert the European project. I am glad that our Renew Europe faction is not one of those. It is part of the agreement on green architecture of the common agricultural policy. An ambitious plan that will better and more effectively protect our soil, water, air and landscape. And that, as you know, cannot be done without agriculture and rural areas. Agriculture and rural development will be part of this solution, while ensuring that their efforts are supported by sufficient support and economic viability. At the same time, it must be a solution that keeps agricultural policy in common and prevents unfair interference with competitiveness. Let us wish that the outcome of our vote this week is not just a mix of opposing shouts, but a clear and thoughtful policy. Only then will we be a worthy partner for the Council and for the Commissioner in the following negotiations. Only in this way will citizens be able to understand how fundamentally and yet viablely we can reform this important policy.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the creation of national strategic plans is, in my view, the major innovation of the new common agricultural policy. These plans will have the immense merit of allowing each state to adapt the CAP to its needs in accordance with the broad common guidelines. They are thus achieving a kind of partial renationalisation of the CAP, which can make the system more rigid and an alternative to an outright return to national agricultural policies. Unfortunately, three problems make me doubt the effectiveness of this new agricultural model. Firstly, the CAP budget will fall considerably and it is not the smokescreen of the EUR 8 billion promised by the stimulus package that will make me forget this reality. The amount of the right to basic payment, calculated per hectare and to which farmers are very attached, will decrease and plunge many farmers into intractable difficulties. Second, the amendments tabled in plenary risk increasing their environmental burden to an unreasonable extent. A proliferation of environmental indicators would lead to the generalization of a private certification system whose cost would weigh heavily on farmers. To avoid this drift, I would like to see a cap on the overall environmental budget at 30% and a focus on incentives rather than constraints. Finally, this forced greening of European agriculture would only make sense if globalised free trade, which promotes unfair competition from non-European agricultural powers, were simultaneously renounced. Unfortunately, we are not going down the road, since on 28 April the Union concluded an agreement with Mexico whereby it agreed to import 20,000 tonnes of Mexican beef per year. In reality, the Commission does not respect our farmers; it has just admitted its cynicism by having Parliament vote on 10 July to allocate EUR 653 million from farmers' funds to migrants from Turkey. I warn you: if you continue to treat agriculture as the fifth wheel of the coach, it should not be surprising that france will one day replace the CAP with a PAF, a French agricultural policy.

name: Benoît BITEAU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the citizens of the European Union are watching us in the hope that the CAP, enabled by their efforts to make the tax contribution and which represents one third of the European Union's budget, will finally meet societal expectations for the next seven years. The eaters of the European Union look at us in the hope that the CAP will preserve vital resources, such as the air we breathe at every moment, like the water we drink, like the food we eat, and that the whole thing is of good quality. The eaters of the European Union are looking at us in the hope that the CAP will incorporate the lessons of the COVID-19 crisis to favour short circuits rather than exporting agriculture, predatory for our ecosystems and for farmers in the South. The eaters of the European Union are looking at us in the hope of a radical commitment to animal welfare. Future generations around the world are watching us in the hope that the CAP, the potential cornerstone of the European Green Pact necessary to preserve their future, will meet the challenges of the climate emergency, the fight against the collapse of biodiversity and the achievement of global food sovereignty. Farmers in the European Union are watching us in the hope that the CAP will finally provide them with dignified living conditions, decent incomes that could pay for ecosystem services that serve the common interest. The time of opposition between economic issues and environmental obligations, an old marmot of liberals and conservatives, is outdated, dated, stale! It is when you are in the red that you have to go greener to get out of the red for good. However, there is nothing in this CAP to achieve these ambitions. On the strength of these observations and expectations, we have a historic responsibility to reject this bad reform of the CAP now, on the substance, therefore, as on the form, since the voting timetable is being accelerated in an unacceptable way, thus degrading the democratic process. We must therefore seize the historic opportunity to draft a new CAP, one that will take us definitively away from these perils and which will meet the challenge of satisfying the best interests of future generations, by making the Green Pact the robust foundation of the future of our children, which is also the guiding principle of this mandate.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are debating the future of the common agricultural policy during the coronavirus pandemic, at a time when European agriculture and European farmers have provided food security to 500 million European consumers. In return, they expect us to prepare them for a much better functioning than before.  My political group has reservations about the high level of environmental and climate spending, but the Polish delegation will nevertheless vote in favour of this level, because it is a solution that benefits smaller farms, and there is a large majority of those in our country. The ECR Group sought to exclude the eligibility of small farms receiving subsidies of up to EUR 2 000 during the work on the CAP reform. That is why, together with the EPP, we have tabled the corresponding amendment – No 283 – and we hope to support it above political divisions. We are convinced that excluding these farms from the eligibility criterion will not jeopardise environmental ambitions, but will be an important step towards simplifying the CAP, as european agriculture expects.  In conclusion, especially at a time of upheaval, which is first brexit for the CAP and then a coronavirus pandemic, we believe that coordinated action is needed to maintain sustainable agriculture and the Union's food security, and this will be served by a reformed common agricultural policy.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, we’ve worked on the CAP file for over a year. Adrian in my office has done over 700 hours on it; and we get a minute to talk about it. We were trying to make an influence on the decision-making that affects a lot of the items: we wanted to help protect family farms; we wanted to help farmers to move away from pesticides and chemicals; we wanted farmers to be sustainable and to produce cleaner food; we wanted to protect biodiversity; we wanted the CAP money to go to the farmers that needed it most, and to stop the 80% going to the 20% that don’t need it. But backroom deals were done between the three big groups; EPP, Renewal and the S&Ds. Lots of nice talk about Farm to Fork, biodiversity strategy, the Green Deal - but they’ve all been thrown to the wind.  This is not democracy. Democracy isn’t about majority voting. Democracy is about giving the people a say. This is not the CAP that the people want. And speaking of democracy - if we turn to Bolivia at the weekend - I’d like to ask the MEPs who supported the right wing coup, to consider apologising to the families who lost loved ones during the year of the coup.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in these months of discussion around the CAP, I have heard of a 'new CAP', but if the new one that is advancing is regionalisation, allowing Member States to manage funds at will in the face of various social and environmental objectives in the further enrichment of those who already have large holdings or inertia in defence of our agri-food excellence, and we are also putting the Nutri-Score on the table. , I sincerely believe that millions of citizens and farmers would easily do without it. We in the 5-Star Movement are calling for a modern, ambitious, environmentalist and European-led CAP. We want the funds to reach those who really live off agriculture with internal convergence that redistributes wealth to small and very small producers and external convergence based on compulsory capping and strict respect for environmental and labour standards, precisely in order to break up monopolies that create distortions in the internal market.  I believe in a CAP and an agricultural sector that can finally really respect core labour standards and also the pillar of social rights. A real link between the CAP and the Farm2Fork and Biodiversity strategies is fundamental, but with clear, ambitious and realistic objectives to gradually abandon all forms of intensive exploitation and achieve food self-sufficiency, based on a new balance between man and the environment, for a nature to be guarded and left to future generations.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this has been a year of complex negotiations, of complex and difficult negotiations, but it has been a year of negotiations that have been necessary, Commissioner, to enable Parliament finally to arrive at a high position, an ambitious, strong position to improve the text proposed by the Commission, which presented – as we have said so many times – a great many shortcomings. , had a structure that was absolutely unconvincing. We know that, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is the time for high ambitions. The challenges of our time, climate change, the strengthening of global competition do not contemplate the possibility of flying low. So the new CAP must contain clear objectives linked to the objectives we have set ourselves here in Parliament on the environment and the fight against climate change, as has also been mentioned here this morning. Socially and ecologically sustainable agriculture is essential for balanced continental and global growth, as we know very well, but this high ambition must be cultivated together with the agricultural world, together with its supply chain, and cannot be imposed from above in any way. That is the fundamental point, so I believe that the compromises reached so far take good account of this aspect which, as far as we are concerned, is straight and contests the priorities that have been expressed by the majority of this Parliament. On the horizontal regulation, in particular, I believe that the compromise reached is a clear signal. Parliament thinks it is a mistake to renationalise the CAP, as we have said on several occasions. We have tried to mitigate the excessive flexibility that was granted to the Member States in the initial proposal, thus returning to a system of control and payment based on compliance with the rules, but at the same time, precisely because we are convinced that we must expect results, when we talk about such a large and important public investment, we have also maintained a control over performance , in two phases, one annual and one biennial, of different intensities, even under stricter conditions, even for the Member States.  We therefore believe, Mr President, that we have struck the right balance between the certainty of not creating inequalities and competition between European farmers, while maintaining the common character of this policy and the control of how the money from this policy is spent which, we must never forget, allows all European citizens to continue to have quality food on their tables.  The last issue I would like to mention briefly is social conditionality. I know that I have run out of time, but it seems to me to be a fundamental issue that we have included in the text and it is very important.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I hope it will work out this time. I will start with direct payments, which remain the most important instrument to support European farmers in their incomes. The problem, however, is that the volume of these payments varies greatly and is not due to objective criteria or production conditions. The volume of these payments depends on the production volume in a given country more than 20 years ago. This breaks the equality of the conditions of competition, it's time to end this historic method.  Dear! Following the implementation of the changes, European agriculture is expected to implement environmental and climate action to a greater extent than before, and that is very good, but in order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to eliminate the pathological situations in many countries that it is not farmers and farmers who are the beneficiaries of direct payments.  In Poland – as confirmed by the Polish Academy of Sciences – as many as 70% of the beneficiaries of payments do not carry out agricultural activities. They are most often the owners of several hectares, that is, they are treated as small farms as priorities, and they are also exempt from environmental measures.  That is why it is so important to define an active farmer in the amendment to Article 4, so that real farmers are subject to agricultural policy and landowners receive rent. No one will lose, they will gain real farmers and the environment, which we all care about so much.

name: Jérémy DECERLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a farmer long before he was a Member of Parliament, in love with my profession, who has been involved for years in the defence of the profession, this exchange on the common agricultural policy that we have this morning is of particular importance to me. I regret that the health situation does not allow us a more serene debate. The reform of the CAP that we are about to vote on is not perfect and there will still be battles to be fought in the next revisions, but unlike some, including our colleagues from the Greens and other groups, who choose the weapon of baseless criticism, misguided spamming and personal attack, I believe that we must first recognize what is going in the right direction. Tomorrow's CAP will be greener by helping those who have already made transition efforts to value them and by encouraging more those who have not yet started to do so. But a greener CAP cannot be done without a more economical CAP. We have a responsibility to defend aid and tools to better protect our farmers tomorrow. I count, ladies and gentlemen, on our Assembly and, during the trilogue, on the Commission and the Council to show as much ambition on the environment as on the aid paid to young people or on the payment of aid per active farmer. For the whiter-than-whiter-than-white agriculture that some people are calling for needs many, proud, free and standing men and women.

name: Sylvia LIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the After a year and a half of inaction, it is completely incomprehensible to me that the votes on the common agricultural policy have now been scheduled in the middle of the COVID 19 lockdown. There are more than two thousand amendments on the table. An eloquent testimony of the inability of the committees to draw up viable compromises. And so today my speech is not directed at Members in this sham debate, but at the citizens and farmers, if they are to listen to it by mistake, because, as always, there is hardly anyone here to debate.  If you want to know how successful the EU's agricultural mismanagement has been so far, you only have to look at the death of the farm. In the last twenty years, the number of holdings in Germany has halved. Many of them operate in ancillary business because it does not last for life, because it is not possible to cope with the investments of the ever-increasing number of requirements. Family farms, which are purifies to protect, will soon be a thing of the past.  The new CAP – you only have to look at the Commission's brief summary to understand where the journey is headed. Nineteen pages explain how the farmer should improve environmental and climate performance. The main priority is more ambitious targets for climate protection, the Commission says, and contrary to what has been said to the contrary, it wants to govern more and more in national agricultural policy and calls on the Member States to submit strategic plans that need to be approved. The farmer of the future: he is allowed to plant hedges, plant trees, see flowers and create nesting places. There is only one thing it is no longer intended to do: to produce food, because the Commission believes that this is responsible for species extinction and pollution. In the meantime, food is imported and consumer protection is undermined. For example, China: 27 000 pesticides are authorised there, which find their way to us via processed foods. By comparison, only a thousand are allowed in Germany.  And the German farmer, beaten with idle associations and a similar government, whose sole priority is the Presidency of the Council, pays the price for distortions of EU competition – the most recent victim is the German sugar beet farmers – and thus finances his own abolition with German tax money.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, thank you very much, good morning and greetings from the Netherlands. We’re going to have a very important discussion today and in the coming weeks and months on the future of European agriculture. I think what is very important is that yesterday again it was once more confirmed by the European Environmental Agency how within Europe we are still losing biodiversity, and there is a direct link with our common agricultural policies and that loss of biodiversity.  So this is the chance to fix it, to really link the CAP reform to the Green Deal, and how that possibility has been missed by the deal of the Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and Liberals. Just to go through a couple of these measures. First of all, there is this voluntary way of dealing with eco-schemes. So it’s voluntary, but if you don’t look at how you can comply with it, we come to very vague terminology like ‘you need to have actions to improve the sustainable use of pesticides’. What does that mean? Almost any measure will comply with these eco-schemes; it’s not meaningful at all.  On the other hand, the price we pay for that is that we are weakening even the general conditions, weakening the proposal of the previous Commission that did not even link it to the Green Deal, so that’s another very clear example that we are just copy-pasting non-functioning conditions from the previous time to this time. And then on top of that, we are even stating that the direct payment should be at least 60%, with that capping the possibility of companies to go even further on greening, and on top of that no link at all with the Farm to Fork Strategy being made.  You know how weak this deal is, you know it very well. That’s why you do all the tricks now to influence the voting list and to make it as early as possible – because you know that the deal is weak and the more it will be scrutinised, the more people will doubt it. So therefore, dear progressive forces in Renew and Social Democrats, follow your own voice and don’t follow this crappy deal that is missing the opportunity of linking this CAP reform with the Green Deal that is so badly needed.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are today finishing work on the common agricultural policy for the period 2021-2027. Support under the common agricultural policy in accordance with the Treaty includes income support, market support and rural support. Unfortunately, the allocation of funds proposed for years has maintained grossly unfair differences in the level of subsidies for farmers in individual Member States and is detrimental to farmers in some Member States, especially the new ones, including Poland.  According to the Polish Sejm, this violates the principle of non-discrimination against citizens on grounds of nationality (Article 18 of the Treaty). Prohibition of discrimination between producers within the Union (Article 40(2) of the Treaty). In establishing the common agricultural policy, account may be taken of differences between agricultural regions and not differences between Member States (Article 39(2) of the Treaty). This discrimination poses a threat to the future of agriculture in some Member States, including poland in particular. That is why I urge you to reflect. The rule of law – yes. Nor should non-discrimination take place.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: Mr President, this House has supported the European Green Agreement and the climate law by a large majority. The necessity and opportunity of the green transition to a new, durable and fair model of production and consumption. And the day has come, today, when we must vote on the reform of the common agricultural policy. If the objectives of the European Green Agreement are not incorporated into it, what transition are we talking about? How do we protect the most vulnerable to the climate crisis, farmers? Are we just going to close the door on any hope our farmers have of living decently from their profession? What opportunity do we have for sustainable, healthy and resilient food systems? What alternative do we have left to prevent catastrophic climate change and the rapid loss of biodiversity? At what opportunity do Europe's rural areas have to remain attractive and humane?  The process, ladies and gentlemen, by which today we decide on one third of the European budget and on the future of millions of people is unacceptable. We have time to work on a truly new and fair common agricultural policy, appropriate for the 21st century, and to demand open real consultations on national strategic plans in our countries. For Greece, the new CAP and its full link with the Biodiversity Directive and the Farm-to-Plate Strategy is a unique opportunity to exploit — at last — its exceptional comparative advantages in the production of quality and healthy food with respect for humans and the environment. Let's get it right at last.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: As you know, this is the first time that the plenary session of the European Parliament has enabled colleagues to speak at a distance from the offices of the European Parliament in the Member States. I note that this innovation, which strengthens both the functioning of the European Parliament and the protection of colleagues from the dangers of the pandemic, works very positively and I think this shows how we can ensure the smooth functioning of the parliamentary institutions of democracy and at the same time protect society from the additional risks due to the pandemic.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Mr President, the GOC is a key pillar of the unpopular strategy of the European Union and governments. Its focus for 2021-2027 is to adapt to the European Union's strategic priorities for concentrating production through various forms: green development under the Green Agreement, digitisation, development of intelligent precision agriculture. These are terms and conditions aimed at increasing labour productivity, which in capitalism are reaped by the monopolies of the European Union in order to be favoured in their competition with other powers, such as the United States of America and Brazil. The 'marble', as always, will be paid for by bio-palestinian farmers who see their crops and animals lost to natural disasters as a result of state abandonment; who are forced to sell their products at below-cost prices to large and large food and processing companies and expect subsidies and CAP-type programmes to be equal to secure next year.  The road to capitalist growth and competitiveness, the CAP and government policy over time exacerbate and always exacerbate and solve the problems of small and medium-sized farming. The solution lies in the organised struggle of bio-populist farmers — along with workers — against their common adversary: the European Union, civil governments and monopolies;

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, the common agricultural policy ensures that the interests of farmers, but also of consumers, are protected at the same time. We are living in a changing world, and the post-2020 common agricultural policy will have to face current and future challenges.  The CAP must ensure more subsidiarity and flexibility to take account of local conditions and needs, but at the same time it must remain united. Member States are obliged not to burden farmers with new burdens not laid down in European regulations. Farmers play a key role in combating climate change, protecting the environment and preserving landscapes and biodiversity. This policy will focus on the environment and climate, developing areas of the European Union, capitalising on social and environmental opportunities.  At the same time, the CAP aims to respond to problems in the agricultural sector. The ageing of the population in the countryside is a reality. Encouraging young people to become farmers is a real challenge, but it will ensure the future of Europe's food security. The use of precision agriculture in Europe is still very low.
