Investment programmes in research and innovation will be a key priority and enable European farmers to align with ever-increasing standards.  The common agricultural policy is a partnership between agriculture and society, between Europe and farmers. Agriculture and the food industry make the European Union one of the world's leading food producers and food security guarantors, providing millions of jobs, and this needs to be strengthened beyond 2020.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of a real global emergency that is manifested in the increasingly frequent climatic disasters affecting our rural areas and our farmers, the demand for radical change cannot remain unheeded. In order to tackle this emergency effectively, we need a common and coordinated approach, so that our farmers can make a further qualitative leap forward in the provision of environmental services for the benefit of the whole community. On the contrary, the proposal for cap reform presented in 2018 delegates enormous responsibilities to the Member States, in fact a renationalisation of European intervention for the agricultural sector and rural areas. That is why, as the Socialist Group, we have demanded that the debate on all three dossiers be reopened, despite the vote of the Committee on Agriculture. This is a choice that we are calling for today as a success, given the crucial steps forward that we have achieved.  Let me therefore thank our entire negotiating team for the incredible work that has been done since the COM dossier, with the strengthening of market crisis management measures and greater transparency along the supply chain to this on the horizontal regulation, through which we want to safeguard the common dimension of the CAP up to the strategic plans. And precisely with regard to the strategic plans, I am surprised by the campaigns launched in recent days by some stakeholders against the results achieved thanks to the incessant work of our negotiating team, steps forward unimaginable until a few months ago, I want to mention just a few. We call for at least 30 % of the funds from the first pillar to be devoted to eco-schemes, the measure defined at European level that should accompany and guide our farmers towards increasingly sustainable production methods. We also want to increase expenditure on agri-environmental measures in the second pillar to 35 %, adding a minimum threshold of 30 % for sustainable investments, in line with the objectives of the Green Deal and precisely in order to bring the CAP into line with these objectives, we also call for a review by 2025 of the strategic plans, taking into account the regulations deriving from the implementation of the Green Deal , all without taking second place to the economic dimension of the CAP, which according to the Treaty must improve productivity and support farmers' incomes.  In fact, we want an even stronger and more competitive agriculture and we cannot forget what our farmers and agricultural workers did during the Covid emergency, endangering their health in order to guarantee the availability of food arrived every day on our tables.  That is why we have worked on an ambitious compromise that can safeguard the social, economic and environmental sustainability of the sector. We are, more than ever, ready to meet the challenges posed by the Farm2Fork and Biodiversity strategies, which must not replace the CAP, but must complement the CAP in guiding Europe's 11 million farmers towards achieving common objectives.  That is why, Commissioner, we expect the Commission to take responsibility for putting concrete legislative proposals on the table, based on rigorous impact analyses, which we as co-legislators will evaluate and try to improve in the interests of our farmers, agri-food producers and all the citizens of the Union.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, what we have on the table today is still not enough to bring the common agricultural policy into line with the expectations of European society. But it's a stage of progress that we must not miss. We want a common policy that connects urban and rural, between east and west, with a balance between local flexibility and common ambition. European agriculture needs a vision, not an aggregator of standards and administrative mechanisms. Our decision must send a clear signal to farmers: we need you! Without you, there's no Green Pact. Because the Green Pact must be an opportunity for society, but also for farmers.  When I see the situation of our farmers affected by drought, the difficulty of generating decent incomes, society's expectations of food, health and the environment, I tell you that we can no longer wait. The Common Agricultural Policy must now be amended and, of course, we will also be able to use the revision clause, which we want in 2025, to take another step on these topics. Any postponement of these changes now would mean delaying by 3-4 years an opportunity to give farmers the means to take an extra step in adapting to new realities. The approach we propose means a decisive evolution of agricultural practices towards more respect for natural resources. Farmers must be able to produce quality food at decent prices, aware that it is in their interest, but also in society, to maintain biodiversity, water quality, soil fertility and reduce carbon emissions. Agricultural practices called ecoschemes, investments in farms that produce without polluting or destroying, advice to connect agriculture to digital, innovation will become the basis of a model of agriculture, with nature and technology as allies to produce healthy food. Certainly public policy for agriculture, food and the environment needs a deep rethink in the European Union, but this stage of alignment must not be missed.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if we were to ask workers, entrepreneurs, the elderly, young people, even the sick, at this time of Covid, what they expect from Europe, what they expect from the Commission, what they expect from the European Parliament, they expect concrete action to save lives and to defend jobs.  It is precisely in this direction that our agriculture can go, if not penalised by European measures. With European resources, jobs can be defended within agriculture and the agricultural chain, and European actions can defend agri-food products, agri-food value, our agriculture and defend people's lives.  And yet Europe after insects at the table – some thought in the past that it was a joke, insects on European tables, insects on Italian tables – today thinks about how to enhance synthetic meat. Here, instead of enhancing the Italian and European agri-food system, we think about how to be with the synthetic meat lobby. It is madness, I understand that there is a business of one billion euros behind synthetic meat, but the invitation I make is to continue to keep the bar still and call steak, sausage, shallots, burgers what is a derivative of the real meat, animal meat and not as some would like to deceive consumers, with Europe's complicity.  Well, I think that this must be fundamental and it must be the direction of travel. Do not deceive consumers, do not offend the Italian Agri-Food and European Agri-Food System, do not go in the direction of the Nutri-Score, do not go in the direction of using names that are related to meat to promote synthetic meat.  No to measures which reward synthetic meat, laboratory meat, which reward the wasting multinationals, but concrete, economic and direct measures which reward our agriculture.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Indeed, the industrialised parts of agriculture in particular are now part of the climate problem. Agriculture would have such great potential to become part of the climate solution. With agro-ecological methods, with methods of organic farming, we can save CO2 and bind it into our soils.  Even if the Social Democrats try to talk about a bad outcome to the negotiations here, there remains a missed opportunity to take a firm stand against climate change, the climate crisis and the biodiversity crisis. Instead, we continue to see world market faith, which in our European Union leads to farmers' deaths and to ruinous producer prices.  Which side the Conservatives are on here is very clear with an amendment by the rapporteur, Jahr, which opposes a mandatory ceiling on subsidies in European agricultural policy. So millions continue for oligarchs, for financial investors, for large landowners and for the agricultural industry! This is a slap in the face for farming and a black day for climate and environmental protection.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, in recent weeks I have received many emails from environmental NGOs calling for more support and ambition for the green architecture of the CAP.  My answer is and will always be the same: if agriculture is not a profitable and competitive activity, environmental protection will be a utopia.  You have to be ambitious, but you also have to be very responsible. All of us who sit in this Chamber must be realistic and show that we have common sense.  I honestly cannot support the direction of this new CAP. I refuse to be complicit, because we are generating a bureaucratic monster, because I do not perceive any will to support young farmers with adequate funds and, above all, because implicitly giving up food for benefiting the environment is going to leave our farmers and consumers completely unprotected from imports from third countries.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: – Mr President, less than a year ago Frans Timmermans presented his Green Deal here. But how green is Europe? If this European Parliament is going to pay eur 383 billion in subsidies this week for more poison, more mega-stables and more pollution? Many citizens think of the climate by eating less meat, by putting solar panels on their roof and by leaving the car more often. Nevertheless, Brussels continues to support billions in aid to the livestock industry, which is disastrous for animals and disastrous for biodiversity, and which emits more greenhouse gases than all the cars in Europe combined. Moreover, Europe continues to subsidize the breeding of bulls for bullfighting and promotion campaigns for meat. To top it all off, the meat lobby has also succeeded in getting us to vote on a ban on names such as vegetable burger and vegaschnitzel. We have better things to do here! I'd say meat industry, get involved in your own sausage! I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, respected colleagues, common agricultural production, i.e. politics, are one of the cornerstones of the European Union. The Common Agricultural Policy and consumer protection must guarantee healthy food for the citizens of Europe.  But they must also guarantee many jobs in agriculture. The current incentive system does the exact opposite: across Europe, many family farms are shutting down and allowing individuals to earn enormous profits and enormous material benefits. In the Republic of Croatia, 80% of all funds go to only a few individuals. What does that lead us to? That those with this amount of money will be able to buy back most of the agricultural land of individual states that takes us back several centuries, and leads us into feudalism.  Furthermore, some regulations are inaudably written, as is the Regulation on the common regulation of the market for fishing products that allows products to be labelled in a way: country of production - Croatia, and then we have a fishing area and you think it is a fishing area in the Republic of Croatia, and it is an area in Africa and Asia. This encourages fishing in Africa and Asia, not in Croatia and the European Union.

name: Juan Ignacio ZOIDO ÁLVAREZ
text: – Mr President, we often engage in debates about acronyms in the European Parliament, but we forget what lies behind it. The CAP is not just an acronym. Behind the CAP are millions of farmers and ranchers from all over Europe; millions of citizens are willing to leave their lives in the countryside to get their family ahead, to build a life project. Behind the CAP is the effort of generations, pride in what has been achieved for years by parents and the illusions so that children can continue to earn a living in the countryside. That's why this week's vote is not just any vote. This week we decided on the future of these millions of farmers and their families and on the quality products at reasonable prices they work with and produce. Despite the council's budget cut on farmers last July, there are still those who want to impose more burdens and demands on them. The Popular Party is the Spanish country party and that's why we're never going to abandon our farmers. We will not tolerate radical change, like the one some propose, for a model as successful as the CAP has been so far. The common agricultural policy has for decades been the master pillar of European construction, and in the People's Party we believe that it must remain so. Otherwise, a Europe without a strong CAP will not only end the future of millions of farmers, but will simply be much less Europe.

name: Günther SIDL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Yesterday, the European Union's Environment Agency proved once again that europe's nature is under threat and that biodiversity continues to decline drastically. Together with the change in the climate, this is a dangerous mix for the future, and we MEPs must take action in every area in which we have a responsibility to take action to counteract this massively. Also and especially in agriculture. This week, we are taking decisions on the direction in which the common agricultural policy will take place in the future. The Green Deal, the Biodiversity Strategy or the objectives of the Farm-to-Fork strategy are not contradictions with EU agricultural policy, no, they must be a strong part of it, as well as animal welfare. Sustainability must determine thinking and action, and farmers must be an active partner in this way. Just as it is important that we, as the European Union, become independent of food imports. Now there is a basic package on the table, where the three largest groups in this House have agreed, including a strengthening of greening, ladies and gentlemen. We must not deny this. This is in the first and second pillars, there is a strengthening of conditionality, and environmental funds must remain environmental funds if they are moved from the first to the second or from the second to the second pillar. In the coming days, however, ladies and gentlemen, it will now be a question of supporting progressive proposals and, in particular, in protecting the environment and climate protection, and of course always keeping an eye on the feasibility of companies. Furthermore, which is of course also very important to my group, we must not forget the social aspect, even with regard to the largest budget pot, and it must even be taken into account. People need to feel why the European Union is there for them. Anyone who illegally employs harvestworkers or agricultural workers or does not provide proper social security should not receive any money from the European agricultural budget.

name: Asger CHRISTENSEN
text: Mr President! Agriculture plays a crucial role in the green transition. Farmers are part of the solution, not part of the problem. In my view, the European Union must support the green transition in agriculture. That is why the agricultural reform on which we are voting today is absolutely essential. It is the greenest common agricultural policy we have ever seen. I am working for agricultural policy to set the course for the next several years of fighting for the climate, the environment and biodiversity. That is why I have fought for the new model, the gross area model. The model ensures that we have more nature, greater biodiversity and simpler rules. We are going to grow something other than cereals, grass and maize, we are also about to grow biodiversity and climate. I hope that most of you will vote in favour of Amendment No 1148. It is important that we work for a coherent agricultural policy in the European Union. That is why we must ensure that there is consistency between the common agricultural policy and the climate law. In the Committee on Agriculture, I am responsible for the climate law, on which we voted earlier this month, here I proposed a focus of the common agricultural policy on farming, i.e. absorbing and storing CO2 in the soil. We need to have some concrete proposals on the table, fortunately the proposal for storing CO2 in the soil got a large majority. In the forthcoming agricultural reform, it is very important that we ensure flexibility and not one solution. There is a big difference between Cyprus in the east, Sicily in the south and Finland in the north. That is why we need to ensure flexibility in the agricultural reform so that the individual Member States can adapt accordingly. We are working for a simpler rule in the common agricultural policy, our farmers need a simpler and more sensible framework. I hope you will all vote for a more sustainable future. A future where farmers are playing into the climate fight. The agricultural reform is the foundation of the farmers' economy and millions of farmers around Europe. We must give them this by voting for the greenest common agricultural policy ever. The European Union must lead the way, only so when we achieve the common goal of climate neutrality by 2050.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Thank you, thank you very much to the President and the good debaters. I'd mention two points in that one minute, if I have any time. First, it is climate policy, climate neutrality and climate hysteria. To this day, no one has been able to prove, even in this Chamber, how much climate warming will be affected if we close all farmers tomorrow, close all factories, stop all CO2 emissions, no one has yet been able to prove how this will affect global warming, and therefore it is very bizarre and funny to hear in this Chamber that we are fighting for climate neutrality, even though no one in this Chamber knows how it actually affects climate warming or climate change in the long term. Not to mention, of course, the ambivality that most of us drive cars to work and fly planes back to our home countries, but we are all fighting here for climate neutrality. And secondly, inequality: we are talking about solidarity, the single market, the European Union's common agricultural policy, but to this day, even in the case of Estonia, we have been a Member State for 16 years, but the Estonian farmer receives a third less agricultural subsidies than the German or French producer. But the market we have one and the conditions are one. This is really the solidarity of the European Union, which we love so much and defend here. Thank you!

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: – Mr President, whoever decided to call this the common agricultural policy (CAP) ‘reform’ might like to check a dictionary. ‘Reform’ would mean improving the current CAP and aligning the future CAP package with the European Green Deal. This CAP should be transformative. It’s not. This CAP is regressive. The recent European Court of Auditors report clearly concluded that declining biodiversity on farmland is a major threat to both the environment and to farming itself. Rules and rewards shape behaviour and practice. CAP must continue to provide vital support to farmers. But that support needs to be both fair and targeted into a transition into improving farming methods that help to stop, not speed up, runaway progression towards mass extinction.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Mr President, greetings to everyone in Prague. The common agricultural policy is, of course, intended to help farmers, but it is also intended to help the countryside and the protection of the environment.  For good water and soil quality, we need to increase biodiversity. Unfortunately, with the intensification of agricultural production, biodiversity is deteriorating. Intensification also grows with the size of companies. We in the Czech Republic have the largest size in the whole European Union and we also see the negative effects not only on the environment. Experts say that changing the subsidy settings would be very helpful, and I see very clearly one instrument that would help us, it is the mandatory capping of subsidies. Mandatory capping of subsidies will help small businesses, family farms, those who, on the contrary, increase and promote diversity. I have therefore proposed a voting procedure that introduces mandatory capping and which would be very helpful to us. I will also send you all my proposal and ask you to support the mandatory capping of subsidies and the reduction of subsidies for agricultural holdings, for huge companies.

name: Chris MACMANUS
text: – Mr President, as an Irish MEP representing a mainly rural constituency, I was pleased to have had the opportunity to work directly on this common agricultural policy (CAP) reform. However, I am very concerned and disappointed at this last minute attempt by the centre ground to weaken the substantial reform of CAP that is needed.  Farming families that I represent need to see a fair balance between a reward for producing food that we eat, looking after our environment and an assurance of generational renewal. Therefore, major reform of CAP must include substantial ring-fencing of the redistributing payment, eco-schemes, a capping of payments at EUR 60 000 and the delivery of full convergence. However, elaborate parliamentary footwork over the last few hours is severely limiting our ability to ensure democratic engagement with these proposals and will make delivery of these much needed reforms much more unlikely.

name: Álvaro AMARO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we have closed a chapter this week which began too long ago and we are doing so today in a very different context from that in which this reform was designed, structured, presented and even negotiated.  It is the vital importance of food, on which we depend, that mobilises us around one of the most important Community policies, but let us not be naïve: the CAP guarantees the sovereignty, security and food sufficiency of Europeans, also reforming practices and methods of production. But the CAP still plays an important role which is like a catalyst for progress. It strengthens the socio-economic fabric of rural Europe and the outermost regions by creating jobs, promoting growth and social inclusion, but never forgetting young farmers. This must be said fairly: rural areas are the ones that contribute the most to improving Europe's environmental performance. Our role this week is to make climate and environmental ambitions compatible with sustainable production. To pass a reform is not to approve a break. We are well known that politics is the art of compromise and the compromise we want to adopt is the best solution, or is the possible solution, for the 27 Member States. We defend it not because it is perfect, but because it is feasible, because our farmers depend on concrete solutions. We do not give in to demagoguery or populism. We are the party of farmers and we negotiate this CAP alongside farmers and consumers. The CAP is, by tradition and principle, Europe's policy. The policy that ensures that Europe has the present and future, the production of solidarity and prosperity of the Union.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Mr President, this week we will decide the upcoming seven years in the common agricultural policy (CAP) and how it will look for EU farming. This is of historic importance and we need to reform the CAP. Unfortunately, the text on the CAP strategic plans, voted in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, fell far behind the ambition of the Commission’s proposal. The work of us progressives has been to change this and make sure that the goals set in the European green deal, the Farm to Fork, the biodiversity strategies, are compatible with the report that we now have in front of us.  I’m happy for the wins – now we have a large percentage of money going to promote the transition to sustainable practices. I’m also happy that some of the fake climate environmental actions are now gone. The conditionality for farmers to receive direct payments have improved to some degree, but I have to say all this could have been stronger. The mixed results of the group consensus means that we have to do more. I urge all in this Chamber to vote for the amendments which aim to secure that the CAP is aligned with the Paris Agreement goals for the Agenda 2030 and therefore gives us some hope that we can create a sustainable future, because this time we have to consider the climate, the environment, animal welfare. Animals are packed together in intensive farming factories and are a threat to our health and to the climate and also, with growing risk of anti-micro-biological superbugs, a risk of transmission of disease, which can lead to new epidemics.  This time, we also have to make sure that bad employers, who use their often very vulnerable workforce in an unacceptable way, are punished and not rewarded with money. This time, we have to vote to do something about the fact that European agriculture is one of the main polluters and emits enormous amounts of greenhouse gases. This needs to change and it needs to change fast.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, greetings from Helsinki! Finally, and finally, we will be able to vote on the reform of the common agricultural policy that is really needed, because the current system and this uncertainty of the situation are too burdensome for the farmer. The compromise reached is an important step towards more sustainable agriculture. I hope that as many of us as possible will take a responsible path and support the agreement that has been reached, even if its content is not perfect for anyone. Solutions can no longer be transferred, we need food security and security of supply. I am concerned that the high percentage requirements for climate and environmental measures that have been set out make food production more difficult. I am pleased that we have received the absurd proposals put forward by the Commission regarding finland's peat fields and the ban on bare land to make more sense. Ear-marking sanctions for cattle and other sanctions of the same type should now finally be eliminated.  As for the ceiling, it should be voluntary for member states. In Finland, it even hits small family farms, which the EU has been urged to invest in. We must not make a contradictory policy. It is regrettable that the Greens are proposing to bring down the entire Commission's proposal and do not support this compromise. We all know that, in such an attention-seeking way, policy cannot achieve the desired results.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The proposal on the future of the common EU agricultural policy has some positive approaches: capping support at one hundred thousand euros per farm. This is to be welcomed and benefits small regional farmers. The proposal to reduce cheap foreign imports is also welcome, benefiting both consumers and local farmers.  Unfortunately, this proposal also goes far beyond any meaningful objective, particularly in terms of environmental protection. The Green Deal has obviously really become something of a fetish for the Commission. With the help of two thousand amendments, they are creating a bureaucratic monster that makes life unnecessarily difficult for our farmers.  And the only thing that is being discussed in public in the midst of the worst economic crisis since 1945 is the name of vegan and vegetarian products and whether the veggie burger can be called burgers in the future. A pointless discussion like I have never seen before – pointless even for EU relations.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Mr President, I must ask: why vote today on amendments that were only going to be voted on tomorrow? It is a coincidence that these will be the compromise amendments shared by the EPP, Renew and S&D. It seems that we are continuing this House’s tradition of business as usual, and scientists say that, if we continue business as usual, we will reach the point of no return in a decade. Seventy per cent of agricultural emissions come from the livestock sector, so EU funding must not be used in any way to support concentrated animal feeding operations. More, we must also stop funding bullfighting with European money. The common agricultural policy (CAP) was created to aid the production of food, not fuel animal cruelty. To end, a final reflection on the veggie burger topic. For years, this has never been an issue, but now the meat and dairy sector are so scared that they are starting to fight about food denominations. But if we care about the environment, animals and public health, we should facilitate the choice of European consumers, not the other way around.

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: Mr President, unfortunately our farmers have fallen victim to the bureaucracy and hypocrisy of Brussels. And I am talking about hypocrisy because, while the Union has a number of outrageous demands from our producers to get aid, through the agreements it signs with third countries it fills the European shelves and feeds Greek and European consumers with lemons and melons from Turkey, olive oil from Tunisia, potatoes from Egypt, honey from China and more. The main problem with imported products is that they are a health bomb, as there is not the slightest control during the production process from third countries. In short, who and under what circumstances will produce. Also, imported products have such low production costs that it is impossible for our producers to compete with them. So if you want to give practical support to Greek and European farmers, reduce imports. Thus, we will have an increase in demand and production of our own quality products and also job creation in the Greek region.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: – Mr President, the CAP directly affects the lives of millions of producers in the European Union, and indirectly we are all beneficiaries of the fruits of the countryside and its ecosystems. Today's struggle is the struggle for territory and for life. The CAP is a tool of cohesion and must now reinforce the green transformation facing Europe. Let us reject this idea that farmers are subsidized taxable persons. No. Farmers feed us, keep rural areas alive and are a climate change containment dam. Some political groups have come here to defend the usual model with a green wrapper. But the CAP of this time is fairer and more sustainable. That is why we demand that the first hectares be boned, because two-thirds of the European Union's farms have five hectares or less. That is why we want there to be a maximum limit on aid, because only 2% of beneficiaries receive more than EUR 60 000. That is why we are defending significant and real environmental expenditure for young people and women as well. That is why we want a strong conditionality, not only green but labor, that guarantees the rights of farmers, ranchers, workers and temporary workers. We are committed to a united Europe in which our way of growing, raising production, trading and consuming is transformed. Today much of what we will be is born.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for the completion of this enormous task and negotiations.  This time, the common agricultural policy will certainly seek to achieve more than ever before. It has ambitious environmental and climate targets, but just as important to me is the special attention paid to the quality and safety of food, young farmers, small and medium-sized farms and generational changes in farms – to name but a few. But we must remember that at the heart of all these ambitious objectives must definitely be the most important one, namely the production of food: high-quality, sustainable and safe European food. And there is always a farmer behind it, and so the farmer must constantly be at the heart of this work of ours. This is important to remember. It is imperative that agricultural production continues to be safeguarded and maintained in all parts of Europe in the future as well. It is therefore very important that Parliament's position also allows us to take account of the specific needs and difficult circumstances of the Member States. I could have talked more about these vegetarian sausages and burgers, but let him stay this time.

name: Isabel CARVALHAIS
text: – Mr President, a long and difficult negotiation in this Parliament which has crossed two legislatures and different Members, and the results of which – at least some – leave a taste of dissatisfaction in many of us. This is the result of the commitments that were necessary to make, imperfect for what are our positions and ambitions as a group, but necessary to make progress. And so, despite dissatisfaction, I believe that it is also time to move towards solutions that can help European farmers in the important challenges for increasingly sustainable agriculture in all its dimensions. And Parliament will be here to exert this pressure of vigilance in this process. I would therefore like to congratulate the outcome of the commitments in the DOSSIER of the CMO Regulation which will contribute to strengthening the position of farmers and defending European agricultural production. Also in the regulation of the strategic plans the commitments now reached represent a positive step towards a basic document that left much to be desired, and for whose progress the S&D played a crucial role, and I also point out the commitment of the Socialists and Democrats to seek to introduce the concept of social conditionality. I would also like to stress the importance of agricultural activity for rural areas, in particular in supporting their maintenance in more disadvantaged areas with natural constraints. To support the maintenance of agricultural activity in these areas is also to support the maintenance of agricultural areas of high natural value, to counterland abandonment and consequently to strive for the preservation of agricultural ecosystems and associated species, and this should also be recognised.

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we are voting this week in the European Parliament on the common agricultural policy, and we know that this is a decisive vote: 30% of the total European budget for the next seven years. Together with my colleagues from the Renaissance delegation and the Renew Europe group, we have two very high priorities. The first is to give more income to farmers who need it, especially small and medium-sized farmers, because you cannot make the agricultural transition, the agroecological transition, if you do not have the means to do so. That is why, for example, we support the capping of aid for the common agricultural policy. The second major priority, of course, is the agroecological transition. That is why, in the compromise, we are pleased that 30% of Pillar I aid, 30% of direct subsidies to farmers, will for the first time be linked to good environmental practices for biodiversity, for pesticide reduction, for climate. But we have to go even further because this compromise is a compromise. We still have the opportunity in plenary this week to significantly improve this reform, notably by voting on the 50 amendments that have been tabled by the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security, which I would, of course, invite you to support. We also support a direct link between the objectives of the 'biodiversity' and 'fork to fork' strategies and the common agricultural policy, for example the 50% reduction in pesticides over the next ten years in Europe.

name: Rosanna CONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the new CAP must first and foremost protect the centrality of agriculture for society and the economy. The battle for ecological taxation is sacrosanct, but it must strike the right balance between environmental standards and support for productivity and competitiveness. We therefore need common sense and flexibility, which we would like to see in the regulation on strategic plans, because the future national plan cannot increase bureaucracy and eliminate good practices established by the regions, such as managing authorities.  I would remind you that there are already sustainable productions, such as rice in Italy, and I would stress that reducing meat production in Europe, the real production, by favouring imports from third countries, risks causing more damage to the environment and consumers, instead of relieving them.  The same applies to tobacco, which must be included on the list of products entitled to access European CAP funding. Covid, gentlemen, has taught us that excessive dependence on third countries in the industrial field is a weakness that Europe cannot afford. Let us not make the same mistake with agriculture, let us support sectors such as wine and honey and let us help our farmers to rise again.

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In the midst of this pandemic, in the midst of this incomprehensible crisis, in which we learn painfully in some cases that too great interventions in nature make us sick, in the midst of these times, do you want to stick to these old structures in agricultural policy? This money is needed for the great change in order to support farmers who want to implement more animal welfare, more biodiversity, more climate protection and less intensive practices on the ground.  This old system, which primarily serves the agricultural industry, which demonstrably pollutes our ecosystems and thus makes us and our planet sick, is man-made. And it is simply being carried on here, and we could change it if the Social Democrats, if the progressive forces were not simply left out of the field. Be a realist and vote with us for a fresh start to the CAP!

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: – (beginning of speech without microphone) ... Cap. I know it's important to continue the process and not block it, but it shouldn't be a bad deal at all costs.  Many important things were not affected by compromises, such as the conditionality requirements for small farms that would literally destroy them. Colleagues from many political groups have worked together to bring amendments and I hope they will save working farmers from bankruptcy and poverty. It is easiest to cut money for real farmers and for families with private farms in favour of more green schemes. In the cultural sector where I work, this has already been done and the budget has been monstrously cut. As we speak of solidarity, many of you are lightly destroying pan-European culture, starting with artists and creative organisations. Obviously, agriculture will be next in an attempt to destroy it.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's vote is crucial: it will commit us until 2027 on a subject - the Common Agricultural Policy - which covers more than 30% of the European Union's budget. Here, I would have liked to tell you about the 4 million farms that have disappeared in Europe in the last 20 years, of those farmers who commit suicide, every two days in my country France, of the extinction of biodiversity, of which intensive agriculture is now the main cause, of climate change or the suffering inflicted on animals in industrial mega-farms. But the Commission, the Council and the negotiators of the major groups in this Parliament have already decided to send us into the wall. Their last-minute opaque agreements and their passage in force are about to sign the death warrant of hundreds of thousands of farmers, biodiversity and climate. So, ladies and gentlemen, do not accept the manoeuvres aimed at silencing us and preventing citizens from getting involved, vote for the rejection amendment to force the Commission to review its copy, because in ten years it will already be too late.

name: Salvatore DE MEO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs and all my colleagues in the Committee on Agriculture for their excellent work in the difficult negotiations to reform the common agricultural policy.  47 % of the Territory of the European Union is agricultural and 22 million European citizens work in this sector. Reforming the CAP means modernising one of Europe's strategic sectors, making it innovative and consistent with the times we live in. This means guaranteeing the quality of our products, strengthening businesses, protecting the environment, promoting animal welfare and supporting the digital development of rural areas and the generational transition of European agriculture. The Covid crisis taught us that for the first time the food chain could break down, but this did not happen. The pandemic, even in agriculture, has made us understand that together we are more resilient, in fact farmers, distributors, processors, wholesale markets have confirmed that working together the agri-food chain is safer, stronger and more transparent for businesses, the environment and consumers. A reformed CAP will enable our farmers to be more competitive, while respecting the environment, by combating unfair competition from countries outside Europe and by guaranteeing consumers food safety and quality as well as a transparent price.  The European Parliament is today launching a challenge for the common agricultural policy to confirm its role of integration and socio-economic cohesion of the European Union, enabling individual states to play a leading role in a strategic sector of the world economy.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Mr President, I want to welcome the green revolution in the future pact and the open perspective with the 'Farm to Fork' and biodiversity strategies that bring opportunities. I especially congratulate the S&D group for the footprint it will leave by introducing the social dimension. Abuses of workers must stop. The amendments that have emerged overnight on a crucial subject – an even harsher capping of payments to farmers – do, however, throw us into a serious paradox that, unfortunately, we have not had time to look at as normal.  That is, we are asking farmers to make huge efforts for climate-neutral Europe, and yet we want to impose ever tougher financial restrictions. We promised Europeans affordable food, and yet these restrictions risk leading to a decrease in current production and an invasion of imports, which, in a poorer market, will dictate prices, dividing us into Europeans with luxury food and Europeans with second-hand food. We promised farmers that we would help them form a new generation, and yet these amendments will drive young people out of villages because agriculture will become increasingly daunting. We ask them to be at the forefront of the fight for biodiversity, and yet we are pushing them to abandon the land that some already can no longer work because of climate conditions and lack of money. It's happening right now in my country, Romania. These amendments, on such an important issue, affect thousands of farmers with fair investment and many debts, in order to punish two billionaire oligarchs who do not represent European agriculture.

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: – Mr President, today it is important to vote in favour of the CAP, which, together with the reforms, will provide many new opportunities.  Ensuring food security in times of pandemic is as important as fair incomes. Green transition and innovation should be secured by an adequate financial framework. I believe that the future of modern agriculture depends on the active involvement of young farmers.  Bulgarian farmers will engage in the fight against climate change and work to provide clean food, clean air and clean water, but at the same time expect to be supported in the green transition by equalizing direct payments, maintaining the levels of tied support, continuing transitional national assistance and decent living in modern infrastructure and quality services in rural areas.

name: Hélène LAPORTE
text: Mr President, farmers and citizens have high expectations for the next common agricultural policy. I regret a budget that is down by around EUR 30 billion compared to the 2014-2020 programme, at a time when the agricultural sector is facing new challenges. However, france will be paying EUR 26.8 billion to the European Union next year - a record for us - and that we need the CAP. A public debate is currently under way on the issues of the next CAP, in relative media indifference. However, the proposals could be included in the national strategic plan which will be the French version of the CAP, thus placing, as it should, the States at the initiative of the decisions. Our agricultural model now faces the ecological challenge of the green transition, but its implementation is to be refined between the new green structure of the CAP and the environmental measures enshrined in the F2F strategy. The European Union's trade agreements, including the SINGLE EU-Mercosur free trade agreement, raise legitimate concerns about the protection of our quality standards in a sector already heavily impacted by the pandemic and drought. Let us bet that the reform planned for the first quarter of 2021 will allow us to develop short circuits and a dignified income for our farmers.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is clear that the EU's agricultural policy as it stands today favours heavily industrialised large-scale agriculture, and at the expense of these important, more small-scale, sustainable alternatives and initiatives that exist. Hundreds of billions of dollars should not go to those who already have the most or to favour methods that can actually, in the long run, cause problems for all of us. After all, the core of agricultural policy should be a solidarity-based conversion fund for the whole of Europe's agriculture, in a sustainable direction.  The farmers themselves know very well, better than most of us probably, that both climate change and loss of biodiversity pose direct and long-term threats to our food security. The three largest groups in this House could use their power for change and improvement. Unfortunately, however, they have more or less joined forces now to defend and keep the old. But I also know that there are parliamentarians in the three groups too who want to see a change. I hope now that you will vote for animals, nature and the future of rural areas.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, the European Common Agricultural Policy started with the aim of ensuring a stable food supply, with favourable prices for consumers and a reasonable income for farmers. The perverse consequence in practice is that In recent decades European farmers have been made dependent on European agricultural subsidies, which are coughed up with a great deal of Dutch tax money and from which Dutch farmers benefit only on the margins. This dependence on the European subsidy infusion is now being abused by the EU to enforce increasingly strict ecological regulations. In Brussels there is no meeting with the farmers, in Brussels the farmers are also meeting. The Netherlands is a small country, but in efficient use of land and in care of the environment we are world champions! The Netherlands can take care of its own farmers, without European bureaucracy. We stand for an independent agricultural sector where the farmer can once again be in charge on his own farm.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Our farmers are a vital part of the EU economy, providing us with food supplies and creating jobs in rural areas. This requires a modern and properly funded agriculture. Without it, the fight against climate change cannot be properly achieved, only at the expense of economic viability. Nevertheless, we must not forget the events of the last period, of the pandemic, during which the food supply has been, and still is, ensured throughout. In the future, however, this will have to be solved from a much smaller CAP budget. We cannot experiment with the new green agreement. The system is new, the outcome is uncertain, flexibility is required. Member States should be free to provide for amounts that may not be used in eco-schemes. The CAP also has an important role to play in preventing migration from the countryside and it is therefore crucial to support sectors facing difficulties. Production-linked aid should therefore be maintained at current levels and transitional national aid should be continued. The latter aid is budgetaryly neutral, but its absence would have a very negative impact on many sensitive sectors. Not least, I would like to stress that we need to make a clear distinction between plant-based products and meat products. Our farmers are both being farmed, neither is directed against the other, both are equally important. However, it is in the interest of all of us to be able to distinguish them well from each other, including their names. I ask everyone to make reasonable, reality-based decisions.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are completing a reform process which has taken us two and a half years of debate. It is a reform that maintains its structure in two pillars but introduces great changes. Therefore, it is not a reform anymore. With the development of strategic plans we are strengthening subsidiarity for States. We were always concerned in my group about the excess of this subsidiarity because of the possible renationalisation of agricultural policy. I hope it doesn't happen. What is important and what have we been defending? That farmers' incomes continue to be supported, which is essential if we want farmers to survive and activity in rural areas. But we need to make a change in green architecture.  It is true that greening has not worked, and that is why society has the feeling that we have to make important changes. And we have to carry them out with this new green architecture, with a conditionality that is being strengthened in commitments, with new echoesquemas, voluntary for farmers, but mandatory for States, with a high percentage of subsidy – 30% according to commitments. All this, moreover, with a percentage of the entire agricultural policy of 40%. These changes must therefore be made so that agriculture continues to remain a key activity in our rural areas and society understands and understands the environmental role it plays. And if we want capping to be approved, the roof for farms — which is important to the Socialists — as a social conditionality or a better role for the regions in the case of my country. I therefore call for the support and approval of the commitments reached by the three political groups. They are important in strategic plans. I also call for support for the single CMO, on which a great deal of work has been done, as with the horizontal regulation. Also for the Socialist amendments, which defend what I have been saying.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Mr President, whatever is said, agriculture is, has been and will remain the profession of risk. To curb this risk, she does not need to be cajoled, or to be caressed in the direction of the hair, nor to be placed under guardianship. In order to meet the multiple economic, health and environmental expectations, agriculture will need more predictability, more capacity for innovation, political coherence, and a level playing field both inside and outside the European Union. A level playing field, I said. Indeed, it is debatable to put an end to more environmentally friendly cultural practices here, even if they are very laudable, if they remain maintained in the third countries that maintain them and export their production to us. I'm going to be told: the boarder adjustement mechanism is here to put an end to this injustice. I'm waiting to see, it's far from a given. In conclusion, I will ask the farmer: that he be a little less exposed to "there is only to," "it must"; slightly less sectarianism; a little more respect; a little more objectivity; and ultimately a little more feasibility. I know it for having lived it.

name: Gianantonio DA RE
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in future agricultural policy, part of the resources provided will be conditional on respect for environmental sustainability, a mandatory conditionality that must not be at the expense of the productivity of our farms. It is not possible for large agricultural countries such as Italy, Spain, France and Germany to be vetoed by European countries where agriculture is of minor importance. The competitiveness of our companies requires greater protection against the indication of protected origin PDO and PGI. Our typical products are the winning weapon both from a production and economic point of view against the standard products that globalization has wanted to impose on us at all costs. There can be no future for the common agricultural policy without the protection, financing of our products and recognition of the work of generations carried out on the ground, which has made these products a world-renowned excellence.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The common agricultural policy is one of the cornerstones of the European Union's single market. This is not only to support and promote rural areas and to achieve ambitious environmental and climate goals, but above all to ensure nutritional security for us, the people of Europe.  Our priority should be to create a level playing field for all farmers in the European Union's single market. We should simplify the rules and reduce administrative barriers, especially for small farms. The regulations proposed by the current Parliament do not, in my opinion, provide such guarantees. Full alignment of direct payments between Member States should be sought. This will make it easier for less developed farmers to meet the new obligations proposed by the European Commission. From here, I appeal for common sense. Let us remember, not all countries start from the same level of economic development! Let us not create divisions, but eliminate differences!

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to say hello from the Czech Republic. Let me start by thanking the farmers who feed the four hundred and fifty million inhabitants of the European Union and do not have it easy at all, because they are being hit by climate change and today also by the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Let us bear this in mind when deciding on the reform of the common agricultural policy. This should, above all, be fairer for the next seven years and must also be directed towards healthy food, soil and landscape protection and animal welfare. Like most citizens in the European Union, I want us to support only active farmers with European funds. We do not want to further promote property-opaque agro-complexes that increase their business at the expense of family farms and small and medium-sized enterprises. I consider this to be a great danger to the countryside, to the protection of the countryside, but also to the whole of European agriculture.  I have therefore proposed several amendments with my colleagues. We want to simplify the use of subsidies for small farmers up to EUR 5 000, we want to limit direct payments for drawing subsidies up to a maximum of EUR 1 million per entity. We are also proposing the possibility for Member States to match subsidies to their farmers at European level. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that it is precisely thanks to European subsidies that we can afford a high standard of food quality, but we cannot afford to continue to support the oligarchs, and I therefore ask that we support amendments to prevent this.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, a necessary reform of the common agricultural policy is on the table today. It is necessary, ladies and gentlemen, for the survival of agriculture, for a viable income for farmers, for attracting young farmers. Because make no mistake, in Europe, a thousand farmers disappear every day.  I went to talk to them.  And I bundled their stories into a book called "Peasant Pride." When you listen to them, you hear the passion, you feel their craftsmanship. But you also see the problems and challenges they face every day. Then you realize more than ever that this reform is needed.  And that reform is also needed to make agricultural policy greener, more in line with the Green Deal. Well, ladies and gentlemen, for some the proposal is too green, for others it is not green enough. I say to you: for me it is realistic and ambitious and will combine agricultural policy with the Green Deal. So be "Farmer's Pride" and vote for this agricultural reform. Commissioner, I would very much like to hand you this book.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, after the epic debates at the height of the pandemic, when the Amazon forests and jungles were discussed here, today we are reaching a new peak in the political debate. At the time farmers' money was discussed, here colleagues in the hall debated whether the burger was vegan or vegetarian and whether it could be a burger if it was vegan or vegetarian. As they say, if it is important to you, honorable — argue! But I cannot agree with the compromises offered by the three largest groups in the European Parliament. Once again, this Chamber proves that when it comes to allocating funds from general taxes, there are no ideological divisions, but always the interest of the old Member States against the new ones is always viewed. The mobility package story, alas, is repeated again.  We have tried to introduce amendments to equalise the percentages proposed by the Council. It didn't work out. This will lead to what – unreliable incomes of farmers and a decline in competitiveness. In fact, we all know what the battle is here – more money for uncompetitive farmers from the old countries. Thus, there can be no effective common economic policy.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: – Mr President, the current CAP reform is the most ambitious of all the measures carried out so far, as it introduces both a new performance-based implementation model and higher climate change targets. For the first time, eco-schemes are introduced and direct payments are linked to the fulfilment of certain environmental requirements.  However, in addition to environmental sustainability, we must not forget economic and social sustainability. Unfortunately, in the new programming period, we will not reach a full external convergence of direct payments. And without convergence of payments, farmers from the new Member States will continue to be more disadvantaged than their counterparts from other countries. Instruments such as transitional national aid and tied support partially offset lower levels of support in countries and have an important social impact in rural areas. I therefore call on you, in the upcoming vote, to support transitional national aid as a tool that provides national financial assistance to vulnerable sectors and farmers.  With regard to tied support, I regret that in the compromise amendment under Art. 86 no greater financial flexibility was achieved to enable Member States to allocate a larger percentage of pillar 1 funds to tied support. In this regard, and given the enormous importance this assistance has to sensitive sectors in some Member States, I appeal to support the 13%+2% tied support.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank very warmly all the farmers who feed the People of Europe every day. Through the COVID crisis, we have seen how important their role is every day. This nurturing function must, of course, remain at the very heart of the common agricultural policy. This does not prevent us from achieving new performance and new goals, in particular, in the fight against global warming or biodiversity. This is already the case: if we look at Europe and compare ourselves to the rest of the world, the agricultural world has generally made efforts, which will certainly have to be more important tomorrow. But we must do so by also having a form of trust in each other, without putting into bureaucracy or administrative tasks and additional burdens on all farmers - and I think singularly of small producers. In the guidelines, we must also, of course, support the smallest farms. To do this, there must be redistributive aid to further support the first hectares, to provide more support to small family farms at European level. Finally, I will end by saying that I am of course joining all the climate and biodiversity objectives, it is a no-brainer. No sector has as many standards as the agricultural sector: health standards, animal welfare, biodiversity... All this is already part of the standards and conditionalities, which will be strengthened: we can only rejoice. But I would really like, once and for all, that every time we look at free trade treaties here, we are actually paying this special attention to them, to avoid ruining the European economy, ruining farmers and, somewhere, not winning the climate bet because of these imported products.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work Through the common agricultural policy, we are signalling what kind of agriculture we are looking for and how we want to shape the future of the sector. The most important message of the strategy agenda at issue today is that farmers are expected to be increasingly aware of the environment. That farmers are increasingly being required to focus on broader climate goals. However, this means more rules and more restrictions to be eligible. However, tightening restrictions and rules can lead to a significant loss of competitiveness for many producers and that production is no longer possible. When imposing restrictions, we must proceed from the fact that we do not cut off the perspective of the future from farmers, because the preservation of agriculture and rural life is essential to europe's future. When imposing restrictions, more account needs to be taken of the specificities of the Member States. For example, for an Estonian farmer who produces on the periphery of the European Union, it is already associated with significant additional costs. At the same time, our production costs are above average and direct payments are significantly lower than average. Nevertheless, I will be hard-hearted to support the compromises negotiated in the vote under the leadership of my good colleague Peter Jahr, even if they are painful. However, I hope that more appropriate solutions will be found on a number of important issues in the course of the trilogue negotiations.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate the rapporteurs on reaching the compromise text, especially my EPP colleagues Herbert, Peter and others. This has been one of the toughest negotiations we ever had and to finally get agreement on some of the key elements is extremely welcome. No, this is not a perfect text, but as always, the sign of a good compromise is when nobody is fully satisfied. However, we must focus on the positives of the agreement found. One, this is the greenest CAP we have ever had and at least 35% of all rural development funding must be used for environmental and climate measures. 30% of investments must be beneficial for the environment. It is more ambitious than the Commission’s proposal and strikes a good balance between ensuring farmers get a fair income, preserving our rural communities and ensuring we secure the production of top quality European food. I additionally welcome the reduction of needless bureaucracy. Coming from a rural constituency I know very well how badly we need simplification and the cutting of red tape. I think this compromise will help in this regard. Most of all this is a good deal for farmers, the people who have devoted their lives, the people who know best how to protect our rural environment, preserve biodiversity and produce sustainable quality food. I hope we will agree with the compromises to put us in a strong position to go with Council for negotiations.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Direct payments are one of the pillars on which the common agricultural policy is based. It is thanks to them that European farmers have the support to produce high-quality, safe and healthy food. Direct payments also eliminate part of the risks associated with agricultural production, which, like no other sector, poses additional risks related to weather or climate change. Such measures are also important for consumers, as they are guaranteed continuity of supply and affordable prices. Unfortunately, although the challenges faced by European farmers, as well as the costs associated with agricultural production, are similar in the European Union, direct payments are still different, affecting unequal competition in the single market. Of course, thanks to the external convergence mechanism or transfers between the pillars, these differences are reduced. It is good that these provisions are also included in the current proposal. However, the equalisation of direct payments between Member States has still not been achieved. I would therefore like to call for support for the amendment that the process of convergence of direct payments should be completed as soon as possible and at the latest by the end of the next funding period. I firmly believe that only by treating all European farmers equally and fairly are we able to achieve fair competition in European agriculture.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, we can spend months discussing figures and echoesquemas, financial allocations, green pact, capping, climate measures and many other issues directly related to the CAP in this House. But I ask you: Have we stopped to think seriously about whether this CAP is the one that best serves our farmers? Is that the one they need? Is that the CAP you're waiting for? Is this the reform that protects the hard work of those who, despite so many difficulties, continue to cultivate the land? The one that responds to farmers who don't know how to cope with water scarcity? Is this the CAP that meets the expectations of farmers and ranchers in the most disadvantaged areas of the outermost regions, such as the Canary Islands, who see with great concern how the POSEI token is to be reduced by abating them from disappearing? Is it the CAP that promotes agricultural employment and generational re-relief?  Honestly, I don't think so. I don't think it's the best PAC possible. Because it is not the CAP they need, nor is it the CAP they expect, nor the one that suits them, nor the one that protects them. And, more importantly, not even the one they deserve.  It is certainly a political and largely distorted CAP. And we cannot reform the CAP by looking at other issues and forgetting about farmers. Because they are the ones who can run out of future. And we cannot and should not leave them without hope, not at least from this my seat.

name: Simone SCHMIEDTBAUER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the For me, the new common agricultural policy has three equivalent objectives: climate protection and environmental protection, of course and of course. However, we must not forget that sustainable agriculture can only succeed if the money also arrives at our farms, with farmers, and if our family farms have a fair income.  We must ensure and ensure that high-quality and regional food supplies are guaranteed. The new CAP must therefore be balanced and set environmental, economic and socio-economic priorities in equal measure. It is also about our quality of life.  In Austria, more than 80% of farms already participate in the voluntary agri-environmental programme ÖPUL – in the second pillar, in so-called rural development. For me, local agriculture is a model here. These services, which some countries are already providing today, must also be able to be taken into account in the first pillar in the new ÖPUL scheme. As a former mayor, however, i am also concerned about strengthening rural areas, the regions. For me, this is the socio-economic component. It's about investment – from education, LEADER programs to care for the elderly, let's not forget that. And I do not want anyone to mispronounce the CAP that we already have. For me, the common agricultural policy is a foundation of the European Union that can withstand any crisis – especially now in this crisis in which we find ourselves together.  That is why this is a compromise that we must make. And this compromise will hurt everyone a little, but it will be a success for us and the basis for getting into the trialogue negotiations at home.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Mr. President. Oh, well. The case of naming vegetable copies for meat products is therefore intriguing. It can easily be used to make fun of the EU – again. There are so many examples of those down there in Brussels losing their sucks – again. Who doesn't remember the examples of the curly cucumbers, the liquorice pipe and the cinnamon snails. I myself have tasted very carefully at what I think. I'm a vegetarian for several years. Because it's one of my ways to contribute to the climate, and then meat-free diets actually fit really well with my body, which is in menopause. However, I believe that plant-based meat copies should find their own names instead of allowing mutiny in the refrigerated counter. I refuse to give in to climate fundamentalism and, in fact, make life easier for lazy food business marketing companies, which want to secure new market share because we consumers are starting to question the carbon footprint of traditional products in the single market. I refuse to help make free citizens in a democracy dumber than they should be in the face of what is really in their shopping basket. And i really want to take great care of the common food heritage in Europe, where the language of what we eat can only get richer and richer. So, of course, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of a sausage being a sausage, everything else is sausage talk. Welcome!

name: Peter JAHR
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for the stimulating debate. I have written down four or five arguments from the sceptics. First, we need more time. I think we have discussed every problem in the last three, two or a year, depending on the situation, and I could say: the words have changed enough, we want to see decisions at last.  Secondly, eco-schemes. I believe that there is a mistake here. Eco-schemes are not voluntary for the Member States, they are mandatory. They are voluntary for farmers, and I do not understand why we have many sceptics about farmers. Farmers are the solution to the problem and, of course, if they have been implemented sensibly by the Member States, they will not give up 30% of their income. The use of environmental programmes so far gives us the courage, and I even expect the eco-schemes to be oversubscribed. Farmers will participate more than there is perhaps money available. Third ly, compromise. It is only a compromise between the three large groups. This is visually correct, but not quite true in reality, because the three have also tried to look left and right. And anyone who reads the compromises carefully will also find suggestions from the other groups in these compromises. The compromises are specially knitted in such a way that they could achieve a broad majority. Fourthly, it is an old system. First of all, we have made a significant improvement in the Commission's proposal and, secondly, the Deliver model, that is, the changeover from action-based to results-based. I could say that if you think through this and understand it properly, it is the biggest revolution since the McSherry reform, since 1992. So together we are taking the opportunity to finally make the common agricultural policy based on results. Keyword: Small businesses are not supported enough. You would have to be an avid supporter of our relocation plans. That is why I am again appealing, my wish: jump over the shadows in part, help us to reach decisions, help, agree to the reform and let us make the world a little better together.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the The common agricultural policy has been an important brace of our Union for decades. A brace that has brought our regions together in all its diversity. These diverse regions offer the citizens of our Europe home and quality of life.  'Unity in diversity', the EU's motto, is particularly true of agriculture and rural areas. Rural life and work have nurtured and shaped traditions and customs, and has given identity not only to rural areas, but to our entire diverse European society. Our group stands by the new delivery model and the compromises that have been reached, Commissioner. The new supply model is a real opportunity to strengthen the diversity of farms in the Member States. I firmly believe that this will protect the environment, improve the climate and preserve biodiversity. And the most important thing from my personal point of view is that it can continue to produce the highest quality foods. It also offers real opportunities for farmers and foresters, because they get planning certainty and appreciation back and can also generate an income. Three key words: Performance must be rewarded – that was our basic requirement. Flexibility for diversity in the regions – we have created through these strategic plans. Simplification in the Member States for the administrative process – this is also guaranteed. Perhaps it is not the best result we have on the table now, Peter, we agree on that, but I firmly believe that we are on the right track and that we can shape the future here. Moving from compliance to performance, and taking farmers with you.  Mr President, I have one more question on the vote on our horizontal list. Why, in accordance with Rule 183(3) of the Rules of Procedure, is not the first vote on the compromises supported by all the political groups and then on those of THE EPP, S&D and ECR? Please can you explain this to me again afterwards? Thank you very much. I believe that we are ready to vote for our European farmers.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It was a fascinating debate, it was an excellent overview of all the major problems of European agriculture, a review made from different perspectives, from different points of view. It is only from such a debate that good compromises and effective solutions are born. Thank you very much for that. Of course, for a short time, I will not be able to refer to all eighty-several speeches that have been made in this debate, but I will address a few in person: speeches on behalf of political groups and some other speeches, especially coordinators from the Committee on Agriculture. Mrs Sander. Maintaining the common character of the common agricultural policy. Others have also said the same thing, and Mr De Castro has repeatedly raised this in our debates. I think we have taken a big step to increase this community character, to strengthen it. Indeed, these commission's initial proposals for 2018 may have been of some concern. I thank the European Parliament, I thank you, members of the Committee on Agriculture in particular, for the discussions that have also been inspiring for the Commission. Eco-programs – 30% mandatory. We intend to put forward some proposals for specific eco-programmes inspired by Parliament. This is a step towards removing these doubts about the Community nature of agricultural policy. On the one hand, we need to take into account the great differences that are between Member States, between countries, regions and sectors, so the strategic plans offer great flexibility. But I think what we have worked out here together will serve to maintain the common character of agricultural policy. Mrs García Pérez. Food security. This, moreover, has been the case in many other speeches. I believe that this reform will strengthen Europe's food security. The fact that we will better protect our land is that, through ecological solutions, we will counteract the devastation of our land, the devastation of the environment, it will increase the food security of our citizens in the long term. Mr Huitema spoke of direct subsidies and, on the other hand, that it would be better for farmers to be able to sustain their income on the market. Well, this is a question at all about the foundations of the common agricultural policy system. However, this was a vision of the creators of the common agricultural policy, who 60 years ago recognised that agriculture is not like any other, only agriculture is an activity that requires support, and that European farmers are unable to compete without this support, especially globally. The difficulties of all kinds that exist in Europe require farmers to have support, and I think that is what we need to continue, there is no other solution here. You also talked about local conditions. I think that strategic plans are a very good place to take these local circumstances into account. This reform gives a lot of room for action in this area. Ms Bizzotto said such important words: "A country without agriculture is a country with no future." I fully agree with this, and I think that what we are doing serves the future of agriculture, that the entire European Union and all the Member States do not become countries without agriculture. In particular, what we are doing for small and medium-sized farms, because this reform – I am firmly convinced and will do my best at this second stage, at the strategic plan stage, to make these farms more strongly integrated into the whole system of the common agricultural policy, so that they are at the heart of this system. This should ensure precisely that the countries of the European Union will not become countries without agriculture and without a future. Mr Häusling pointed out a problem that obviously worries us: 80% and 20%. 80% of farmers, the smaller ones, take only 20% of EU funds and up to 20% more go to 80% of all funds. However, I believe that, thanks to eco-programmes, these proportions will change, perhaps not to the satisfaction of it, but eco-programmes – mr Kuźmiuk, among others – this is a good solution for small farms. Here I want to express my deep conviction and also to declare some of the Commission's action in favour of small and medium-sized farms, but especially for those small ones that are very often out of this competition today, disappearing, losing them at a very rapid rate – four million farms in a decade.
