text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Sven Mikser's report on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on a recommendation from the European Parliament to the Council and the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy in preparation for the 2020 Procedure for reviewing the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT), nuclear arms control and nuclear disarmament (2020/2004(INI)) (A9-0020/2020). In this debate, too, neither spontaneous speeches nor blue cards or requests for speeches on a point of order are allowed. There are no registered ones, but in theory we would also provide for online connections from the Member States.

name: Sven MIKSER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the NPT or the Treaty on the Non—Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons entered into force over 50 years ago, in March 1970. The Treaty consists of three mutually reinforcing pillars which deal respectively with the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, nuclear disarmament and the civilian use of nuclear energy. The Treaty has been joined by 191 nations, which is the overwhelming majority of the global community, including all five of the recognised nuclear weapons states. As such the Treaty represents the only binding commitment by the five permanent members of the UN Security Council to work towards global nuclear disarmament.  At the 1995 Review Conference the Treaty’s duration was extended indefinitely. A review conference of the Treaty is held every five years, but regrettably every other one of those review conferences in this century has ended without a consensus regarding the final document. Therefore I believe that it is of critical importance that the 50—year anniversary review conference, already postponed once because of the COVID pandemic, be a success.  Our 27 Member States joined the NPT as individual nations, but I believe that in order to contribute to the success of the upcoming review conference, it is necessary that a strong consensus position be forged among the EU Member States. The recommendations to the Council that we are going to vote on at this week’s plenary session are aimed at helping the Member States to agree on such a position.  I would argue that regarding its central objectives, the NPT has been relatively successful during the past half century. The nightmare scenarios painted during and after the Cold War regarding the proliferation of nuclear weapons to dozens of countries around the world have not materialised, and after the end of the Cold War the nuclear arsenals of Russia and the United States were brought down significantly from the peak numbers of warheads. Yet significant problems and challenges remain as many of the objectives of the Treaty have yet to be fulfilled and some important stones in the nuclear disarmament and non—proliferation architecture are still missing. The CTBT, or the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty, negotiated in the 1990s is still awaiting ratification by a number of its Article 16 countries, and the proposed Fissile Material Cut-off Treaty is still under discussion at the UN Conference on Disarmament, with not much tangible progress to show during the past several years.  Moreover, even though a vast majority of the global community of nations have joined the NPT, there are still some outliers, including countries that are known or believed to be in possession of nuclear weapons or are believed to have pursued nuclear weapons programmes in the past. It must be noted that, with the exception of the five nuclear weapon states, all other countries are only able to accede to the NPT as non-nuclear weapon states. While the immediate accession of the remaining outliers is thus not likely, a question remains as to how to make sure that they would not contribute to global or regional proliferation of nuclear weapons materials and know-how. There are additional clouds on the horizon. Over the past several years, we have seen gradual erosion of important arms control regimes that have for decades been a critical element of European security. Following the consistent violations by Russia, the US has left the INF, the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, last year. The future of the JCPOA, the so-called Iran nuclear deal, remains uncertain. The US announcement that it would leave the Open Skies Treaty throws in doubt the future of an important transparency and confidence building instrument. As the New START Treaty is expected to expire next year it is inevitable that the growing level of tensions and mistrust do not contribute positively to the atmosphere of negotiating its successor. Yet when it comes to the future of nuclear disarmament, it is the two countries in possession of the bulk of global nuclear arsenals that bear the greatest responsibility.  Perhaps even more worrisome is the increasing reliance by some nuclear weapon states on those weapons in their military doctrines. With nuclear disarmament efforts having stalled significantly, a new delivery system is being designed and built, the danger of intentional or unintentional escalation involving the use or effective use of nuclear weapons is growing. All that is why the success of the NPT Review Conference is of utmost importance for global as well as European security.  But let me end with a word of caution. It is clear that our eventual goal must be a nuclear-free world and the elimination of nuclear weapons, but it is a goal that we must approach pragmatically, evaluating very carefully both the immediate and long-term security consequences and implications of each step along the way. A nuclear-free world cannot be negotiated and agreed upon without the participation of the five nuclear weapon states. No false parity must be created between the five nuclear weapon states and those actors that are pursuing nuclear weapons illegally.  While on the one hand every nuclear warhead less is a step towards a more secure world, it is also true that the world where the only remaining nuclear weapons are the illegal ones is not a safer place for us to live in. Therefore I strongly believe that while looking for all possible alternative avenues to reach our eventual goal, we should not choose the ones that risks bringing the time-tested NPT and its review process to a standstill.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and all Members of Parliament who have contributed to these recommendations ahead of the 2020 Review Conference of the Parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. This upcoming review conference is the next most important event on global non-proliferation and disarmament – at least what remains of it. Despite current uncertainty about when the conference will take place, it remains the most important event in the world on non-proliferation and disarmament. We are all concerned about the deteriorating security environment and the continued pressure on the nuclear non-proliferation architecture, as illustrated by the demise of the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty. We very much regretted it when it happened and we continue to regret it now.  It is essential that all state parties comply with their Non-Proliferation Treaty obligations and fully implement all commitments under the Treaty. Upholding and preserving the Non-Proliferation Treaty must remain a key priority for European Union foreign policy. The European Union strongly supports all three pillars of the Treaty – non-proliferation, nuclear disarmament and peaceful use of nuclear energy – and we will continue to promote a comprehensive, balanced and full implementation of the 2010 Review Conference Action Plan.  Through intensive diplomatic engagement, backed up by the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), under the Council decision we are promoting the ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and the preparation of negotiations for a Fissile Material Cut-off Treaty. We are also proud to support the regional conference in preparation for the Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference. We are also going to double our efforts to uphold international norms, to restore dialogue and trust, and to promote transparency and confidence-building measures. Together with Member States, we are preparing a strong and forward-looking common European Union position for the Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference, and I would like to stress some of the key elements of our position in the context of your report. First, we will continue to call strongly on the United States and Russia to extend the New START Treaty before February 2021, and we will encourage negotiations for a broader future agreement. Second, we welcome the various initiatives for nuclear disarmament, including the Stockholm Initiative. Third, we acknowledge the increased attention given to risk reduction and we hope discussions on this topic gain broad support.  The promotion of universal adherence and the entry into force of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, as I have already mentioned, remain top priorities for the European Union and this conference will also provide an opportunity to address the non-proliferation crisis. We continue to call on the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea to refrain from further provocations and to take concrete steps towards abandoning all its nuclear weapons and ballistic missile programmes.  We will also reaffirm our commitment and support for the Iran nuclear deal, the so-called Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). We deeply regret the United States’ 2018 withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal and the subsequent reimposition of UN sanctions on Iran. At the same time, we are gravely concerned by Iran’s activities that are inconsistent with the JCPOA and have severe proliferation implications. Finally, let me underline that we also take due note of your proposal to encourage talks on the possibility of a multilateral ballistic missile treaty. Thank you for all your comments, observations and proposals. Mr Mikser, Honourable Members, I look forward to listening to your views and I thank you for your attention.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr High Commissioner for Foreign Affairs and The Commissioner for External Affairs, ladies and gentlemen. We must remember the devastating destructive power of nuclear weapons. We must also ensure that it is not forgotten how unlike all other weapons are nuclear weapons. And we know that in the past there has often been talk of deterrence and of the fact that mutual deterrence would provide a certain degree of security. That is certainly true to some extent, but even better than deterrence, namely much better, is disarmament in the case of nuclear weapons.  I am therefore glad that the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty exists. I am not glad that only three EU Member States, namely Ireland, Malta and my own country, Austria, have already ratified the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. I would also like to remind all of us that there is also a great danger that non-state actors can acquire nuclear weapons, and the devastating effects of acts of terrorism with nuclear weapons are almost unimaginable.  I think it is right that the United States and Russia are negotiating a successor agreement to the START agreement already mentioned by the High Representative for Foreign Affairs. I think it is good that this is taking place in the capital of my home country, Austria, in Vienna. I think it is bad that China is completely evasing itself. I think it is bad that China simply does not participate in such negotiations, but we should not shy away from reducing nuclear weapons, disarming them and – yes – also believing in a nuclear-weapon-free world one day.

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has There are fifteen thousand atomic bombs in the world, and a single atomic bomb today has a multiple, a dozen times the explosive power of those bombs that were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The nuclear arsenal that exists in the world could destroy the world 150 times, and Russia has spent TEN billion US dollars in 2019, the US 35 billion US dollars and even France five billion dollars on its respective nuclear arsenals.  What I want, ladies and gentlemen, is a world free of nuclear weapons, and that requires a strong, functioning international control system. The Non-Proliferation Treaty is central, especially since the end of the INF Treaty. The US and Russia must quickly restore the dialogue on disarmament and arms control, including China.  And the goal of a nuclear-weapon-free world also includes creating a nuclear-weapon-free Europe. A Europe in which no nuclear weapons are possessed, but in which no nuclear weapons are stationed by other powers. And that includes a nuclear-weapon-free Middle East – that, too, is a very central concern for me. In addition, more effort and implementation is needed in ratifying the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which was also initiated by my own country, Austria. We need to put more energy behind this – that is what is needed.  Albert Einstein, ladies and gentlemen, once said that man invented the atomic bomb, but no mouse in the world would construct a mousetrap. Let us work on a world free of nuclear weapons!

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, this year we celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT). This Treaty is a great success. Of the 191 states that have signed up, only nine have nuclear weapons. This is a much smaller number than anyone could have predicted when the Treaty entered into force 50 years ago.  Our biggest challenge now is to make North Korea and Iran adhere to the Treaty. If not, why would any of the other signatory states do so. Saudi Arabia has already declared it will develop nuclear arms if Iran has access to a nuclear bomb, and Turkey might very well follow suit. In this environment, we should not blame Israel for having nuclear weapons. They are essential for its survival. The EU must continue its efforts to stop Iran from developing nuclear weapons, preferably via the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, but if Iran is not willing to honour its engagements, we will have to find other means. North Korea will not be persuaded by the West alone. For that, we need the Chinese on board. I am afraid that as long as China does not see a North Korean nuclear weapon as a problem, it will be difficult to make any substantial progress.  To conclude, the European Union must continue to promote the NPT and that its Members honour their commitments. We must pursue this in close cooperation with other democracies, because a rules-based world order is our best chance of ensuring peace.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, the subject of nuclear power is the perfect embodiment of the impossibility of diplomacy that is purely European. A tool of sovereignty par excellence, the atomic bomb, on which deterrence and therefore peace was built, is now, since Brexit, the only property of France in the European Union. Except to share this deterrence with our neighbours, European sovereignty does not exist. Germany would of course like this, reinforced by the contradictions of Emmanuel Macron, but it is out of the question, for the defenders of a Europe of the nations that we are, whether this tool is shared or diluted. Only the nation-state with the inalienable right to defend itself is the legitimate framework for the use of this supreme force. The NPT, while a necessary guarantee of stability and balance, cannot prevent our sovereign nation, France, from possessing this tool. I also warn this House against the Nuclear Weapons Ban Treaty that is now behind the NPT. This treaty will not serve the cause of disarmament. No state with nuclear weapons will sign it and does not displease the most naïve, the atom will never be deinvented. More than incantations, our group prefers to focus on the three subjects that really threaten the security of the European continent: Turkey, Islamist terrorism and the widespread weaponization of space.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Mr High Representative, the European Union and its Member States, including my country, France, can play an important role in nuclear disarmament. This force of initiative is now sorely lacking as nuclear arms control agreements collapse one after the other and the risk of deliberate or fortuitous nuclear detonation increases. The recommendations we are giving today to the Council and the High Representative of the Union are therefore of major importance. We can stand back, and wait for the harmful policies of the governments that hold these arsenals to produce disastrous effects, or we can be part of the historic approach and momentum of a disarmament initiative for our collective security. The 1968 Non-Proliferation Treaty already had an obligation to negotiate disarmament. To fully support its implementation, this Parliament must give its clear support to the Nuclear Weapons Ban Treaty. When it was adopted in 2017, some said that the treaty, which angers those who believe in nuclear power and deterrence, would struggle to enter into force. Today, it is imminent to come into force. Within our Union, Austria, Ireland and Malta have already ratified it and new cities are supporting it. I hear some of the talk of realistic disarmament. The only realism I wish to arm myself of is one that chooses to protect citizens and to advance the achievable goal of a free world without a nuclear threat. Ladies and gentlemen, I therefore invite you to support the intergroup amendments I am carrying on behalf of the Green Group to ensure that this report lives up to its mission.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Seventy-five years ago, US nuclear weapons were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. A force of destruction, for decades man and nature felt the consequences. An important lesson from this was the Non-Proliferation Treaty, but disarmament is being reversed.  But not even the threat of nuclear weapons is acceptable! It is a fallacy that nuclear weapons mean greater security. The earth is still full of thousands of nuclear weapons, and it is contaminated by them. The German Air Force is currently training with Belgian, Dutch and Italian fighter jets and is practicing the dropping of atomic bombs. Behind the scenes, Germany is negotiating with France to gain more access to France's nuclear arsenal.  Do we really want that, ladies and gentlemen? No! Europe must become a nuclear-weapon-free zone. U.S. weapons also belong to disarmed. The whole world must become nuclear-free. French, British, American or Russian atomic bombs, all atomic bombs, must finally be wiped out, so that all lives cannot be wiped out. To this end, the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons must also be signed by all EU Member States, without exception all.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, the deterioration in relations between nuclear-armed states, the campaigns to modernise arsenals and launch systems, the collapse of the INF Treaty and the negotiating stalemate of the START Treaty, the exit of the United States from the Iran nuclear agreement and the Open Skies Treaty, the dangerous rhetoric about the usefulness of nuclear weapons are all extremely worrying signs of a resumption of the arms race that the world absolutely cannot afford.  That is why I am convinced that postponing the tenth NPT Review Conference should be interpreted as a real opportunity. As Europeans, we must once again strongly reaffirm the centrality and essentiality of the NPT, and indeed relaunch, be even more ambitious, because the alternative is simply terrifying.  Let us take advantage of this additional time to intensify the dialogue, both with those actors who share our own concerns, suggesting new joint initiatives, and with the actors who are distant from it, seeking compromises on all those issues that risk complicating or even undermining the success of the conference. It is therefore essential for the Member States to arrive at the conference with a strong and coordinated position at European level, also based on the position that we will vote on in this plenary, which clearly states that international peace and security are strengthened in a world free from the existence or proliferation of nuclear weapons, that nuclear disarmament does not just mean a reduction in the number of active warheads. , but also the downsizing of the military and political role assigned to this type of weapon.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I thank you and the Honourable Members for all your contributions to this important debate. Some of you have mentioned figures in the region of 15 000 nuclear bombs. Why so many? This a clear evidence that human intelligence could be used in a better way. We are firmly convinced of the enduring values of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Upholding the integrity of the rules-based international system, with effective multilateralism as a key principle, remains the European Union’s objective. We need to continue working to achieve results and not allow the pandemic to bring multilateralism to a standstill. The field of nuclear prevention is one of those in which we can and should continue working.  Downgrading international treaties and regimes and adopting unilateral measures to enforce compliance with non-proliferation will hardly have the desired results. The major global challenges of our era can only be addressed by working in partnership with others. This pandemic that affects all of us should not stop us from continuing our diplomatic and political engagements to deliver results on the critical issue of the non-proliferation of nuclear arms and nuclear disarmament. I can assure you that we will continue to remind Member States of our common positions and we will continue looking at what else we can do in order to look for common ground and avoid further polarisation. I can assure you that we will continue to encourage the United States and the Russian Federation to seek further reductions of their arsenals of both strategic and tactical, as well as deployed and non-deployed, nuclear weapons.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The amendments will be put to the vote this evening.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on police violence in the EU (2020/2823(RSP)). I repeat that, during this part-session, the debates do not give catch-the-eye speeches on request, nor do they accept blue card issues or points of order. I would point out that it is now possible to speak remotely from the liaison offices of the Member States.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the commissioners for their excellent work and for the work they have When we exchanged views in this House in June of this year about the tragic events in Minneapolis, we were all united in grief and anger at the brutal murder of George Floyd. For many of us, this has only been the tip of the iceberg, because we experience such things in far too many places. Now anger and sorrow are required, but it is even more important that appropriate consequences be drawn from it. The Council expressly agrees with what you, honourable Members, have said in your resolution. Now it is always difficult to draw parallels between what is happening in the United States of America and developments in the European Union. Nevertheless, it is absolutely clear that all the Member States of the European Union must ensure that the use of force by law enforcement authorities must always be lawful, proportionate, necessary and last resort.  We have a number of instruments at EU level to put this important understanding of the work of our security authorities on a firm footing. I would like to mention just a few examples and, above all, to highlight the important work of the EU Agency for Law Enforcement Training – CEPOL. Respect for human rights in law enforcement activities is regularly placed at the heart of the relevant offers to the security authorities. Issues such as unlawful profiling, police ethics or the detection and combating of hate crimes have been a mainstream part of CEPOL's training for law enforcement professionals in recent years. I would like to highlight one more point, honourable Members. More recently, a great deal of emphasis has been placed on prevention, prevention instead of coercive measures. The European Crime Prevention Network has been formally affiliated to the Council's Law Enforcement Group and the Council adopted conclusions on certain aspects of European preventive policing in 2019.  We all know, of course, that the protection of national security remains the sole responsibility of the individual Member States. This is guaranteed in Article 4 of the Treaty on European Union and also in Article 72 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Nevertheless, there are various EU legal instruments which, above all, help in cross-border police cooperation between our Member States, that what the security authorities do improves and is always consistently based on the principles of the rule of law.  In this respect, each Member State still decides for itself on the structure and organisation of its prosecution. Precisely because this is the case, it is so important to reach common agreement on the principles of the rule of law, which must be strictly observed by all Member States. We need sound systems for effective judicial review and effective remedies. This is particularly important in cases which you have also mentioned here as an example in your remarks. This is mainly about investigations by national authorities, it is about the work of parliamentary committees and, of course, it is also about the internal police investigation services.  Let me make it clear once again that all the Member States of the European Union are obliged, together with their national authorities, to prosecute any criminal offence found and to take all other appropriate measures. We are currently having some controversy in the European Union about this. I would like to highlight the debates we are having in my own country, Germany. There is a broad debate there about institutional racism. We have now decided on the part of my government that we also want to review the security authorities and, in particular, the police authorities, where there is a need for readjustment, where we need to improve and where there is also a lack of a common understanding of a clear commitment to democracy and against racism.  This commitment by all the Member States and this common commitment are also important, above all, to the policemen and women, who do an excellent job on a daily basis in order to protect our liberal democracy and our constitutional states from the enemies of democracy. It is precisely these police officers, the employees of the security authorities, who deserve respect and recognition.  This makes it all the more important that we emphasise once again that the commitment of the Member States to It is aimed at doing everything possible to correct such errors, to make a clear commitment to a strong rule of law committed to freedom and democracy, and to ensure that our security authorities fully respect and protect democratic values and fundamental rights, throughout the European Union and in its 27 Member States.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank Members very much for this debate. I think it’s a very important topic to debate in this Parliament.  Let me start to tell you about Rissa. Rissa Seidou is a young policewoman in Sweden. She’s black. She says ‘the best part of this job is to build trust in the police. We are here for young people. If we succeed in getting someone to leave the criminal path, trust can spread’. That is so right, law enforcement is about trust. Trust in society. Trust in our ability to protect people. Trust that we protect all people regardless of nationality, their sex and their sexual orientation and the colour of their skin.  In Europe we trust the police. It’s normal to go up to a policewoman or policeman to ask for directions. It’s normal to not be afraid when you report a crime. But Black Lives Matter reminds us it’s not normal for everyone in our societies. And not just in America. Sadly, cases of illegal police violence are also reported in Europe.  I firmly condemn all forms of illegal or disproportionate use of violence and discriminatory practices by law enforcement authorities. That goes against the fundamental rights and values upon which our Union is founded. Any use of force by law enforcement authorities should be proportionate and justified, otherwise we’ll lose trust. To build trust takes a long time, but it can be lost in an instant.  So we must always work hard on trust because people should be able to trust law enforcement authorities and because European policing is based on trust. European policing is community policing. We can only police effectively if we have constant cooperation and the trust of the community. Policemen and policewomen have an important and difficult job. They keep people safe from terrorists and criminals. I admire the police officers who fight child sexual abuse, who face terrible crimes and trauma in the line of duty.  Police put their lives at risk just doing their job. Last week a police station was attacked in Paris and a gunman shot and wounded a police officer in Zagreb. People join the police because they want to help and protect people and protect fundamental rights. We owe it to these policemen and policewomen to strive for zero tolerance towards illegal and racial violence.  Of course, the European Union has limited competence in this area, but we are a community of values. Member States should promote and respect law enforcement rules in line with their national constitutions in full respect of human rights. Each incident of disproportionate or illegal use of violence brought to oversight bodies should be systematically subject to an in—depth administrative or judicial inquiry. National authorities should investigate individual cases and ensure that justice is served. They should publish the results of these investigations in order to build trust. But there is, of course, a lot that the European Union can do. This discussion is linked to the wider debate on institutional racism.  Our new EU anti—racist action plan includes action for fair policing and protection. For example, training and sharing our best practice at EU level to prevent discrimination, including racial or ethnic profiling, in law enforcement. Training is also key. The European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL) can support Member States. CEPOL’s EU—level training could help create a common understanding of human rights and ethical conduct. What we lack is data. We will gather data on police attitudes towards minorities as part of our anti—racist action plan. What I also can and will do, is to put the topic on the agenda, coordinate and work with our agencies. I know Member States are already taking their responsibility. They already have, and still are, putting programmes in place to make sure that law enforcement upholds values and to prevent racism and xenophobia. But I want to make sure that we work together on this. Together with Europol and the German Presidency I am exploring an initiative to assess these existing programmes with European police chiefs, to share and promote the best practice and to identify possible common actions in the future.  I really look forward to listening to your contribution to this important debate.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like us not to have this debate at all today. However, we must not remain silent. The reason we are here is the tragic story of Jozef Chovaovec. A Slovak citizen who died in police custody in Belgium following a dehonest intervention by police officers. Unfortunately, we are aware of several similar cases of police brutality from other European countries. Also in Slovakia, I have cases where police officers attack citizens just because they have a different skin color and the system subsequently protects these police officers.  The test of genuine Europeanity is therefore our ability to face up directly and in the face of all tragic cases of police brutality.  We need a sincere effort for truth, justice and redress in the case of the death of Jozef Chovaovec. In Europe, it must be the case that cases of police brutality are not concealed and obscured, they are dealt with immediately. Police officers on duty can never be the true guardians of the law in European democracy. Shocking footage in the case of Jozef Chovaovec shows that both civil and police training has failed in the Belgian security forces. We would not have discussed the death of Jozef Chovaovec today, had it not been for the mediated footage from the police cell and the pressure of diplomats and MPs. However, today's debate is neither a solution nor a patch on the problems that led to the death of a man who could and should have lived.  There's no problem if we refuse to admit it. This is true in many countries. This is also true in Belgium, which I believe will soon give Joseph Chovac's family truth and justice in the event of his tragic death.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Police violence in the EU: it is about far-right and racist chat groups, swastikas, Hitler salutes, calls for violence and violence resulting in death. In recent months alone, a number of such cases have come to light in several European countries. No, our police officers are not under general suspicion, but the cases show that there are problems. And it is our police that depend on trust and respect for the people.  That is why we need independent studies of extremism in the police everywhere. We need external reporting points for affected persons and police officers, including personal advice and regular evaluation and consistent investigation of reported cases. Racism and extremism threaten our democracy and must therefore be combated in all areas of our society.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to start by expressing my sympathy for the widow, Mrs Chovancova, and her little girl, because it’s quite horrible that she was forced to publish the video of the violent death of her husband. As to excessive police violence, incidents will always occur but what sets apart democratic rule of law from dictatorships, for example, is that there is a follow—up, that there is no impunity for excessive police violence. Here there is a big question mark over this case. The question is why was there no investigation? Why did we have to wait for the video to be published before the Belgian authorities started to move? And when are we actually going to get responses to these questions? This is not just a Belgian matter or a Slovak matter, because it concerns a Slovak citizen. It is very much a European matter because if one national system doesn’t function then the whole chain is broken. In the context of police and justice cooperation, we have to be able to rely on each other and to trust each other, and here there is clearly an issue and we need answers. That is also why the Democracy, Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights Monitoring Group is taking up the issue and this week we’re going to have a hearing. We will also be hearing Ms De Bolle, who is the head of Europol, but also the head of police in Belgium at the time. Finally, with regard to the broader issue of excess of police violence and racism, which has also been addressed by the Commissioner, I would like to repeat the call for a European police code of ethics, but also, I think, for training because in this case we are still waiting for the answers and the motives behind what happened, but I think many police people will also confirm that there are lots of police people who are just not adequately equipped for this kind of situation.  So I hope we get answers because it’s in the European interest.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has I am speaking today from the European Parliament's EU Liaison Office in Munich. I am aware that police forces around the world today tend to be accused of being out of control, racist, institutional brutality and in need of reform.  I would like to offer an alternative view. The police are constantly attacked for doing their job and are under attack even if they do not monitor civil unrest. There are cases in France where police officers have been shot by drive-by attackers. Similar incidents have also been reported in the United States and other countries. Only a few months ago, unspeakable acts of violence against police officers took place in Stuttgart and Frankfurt.  Our police forces face an impossible task: to protect society from itself, but not a few people who are to be monitored by the police want to bring down the society as we know it.  We must not give way to these misrepresentations of police assaults. If individual police officers cross borders, this will of course be punished by the courts. We must not condemn our police simply because political correctness seems to be rewarding violent anti-social troublemakers who have jumped on the latest fake issue. Our task as politicians should be to strengthen our police, not to fall in the back of them.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Europe must act in the face of cases of police violence in the States.  Many of these abuses hide racist motivations, such as those perpetrated against the Roma people. But they also happen during demonstrations of various kinds. In Catalonia, for example, police brutality has been especially against the Catalan republican movement, leaving physical and psychological wounds difficult to heal. Add to this the news of links between different European police forces and far-right groups.  Under no circumstances should the police infringe human rights. On the contrary, you must protect them. For this reason, we propose the creation of an independent system for the control of police violence within the mechanism for the rule of law or the revision of the Directive on the protection of victims.  The Union must recognise the need to monitor police conduct, ensure accountability and an end to police violence to protect the rights and freedoms of all citizens.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, Jozef Chovanec, Tomy Holten, Rashan Charles, Sheku Bayoh, Karol Sendrei, Roland Dančo, Robert the Fisherman from Moldava nad Bodvou. These are the names of only some people who have experienced or succumbed to police brutality within the European Union.  Up to 63% of victims of physical and racist attacks by police officers will never find the courage to speak openly about their cases and report them. Jozef Chovanec died after a brutal intervention by Belgian police accompanied by extremist speeches. For two and a half years, nothing happened in this case, trying to cover it up, sweeping it under the carpet, and if it wasn't for his wife's courage to this day, we wouldn't even know what happened at the time. In June, we adopted a resolution in Parliament on George Floyd, the American citizen, fine, I also supported it, I am very glad that we responded in this way, but I have to say that, with the Slovak citizen, a citizen of the European Union, we and some Slovak colleagues have had to overcome a number of obstacles, but I am glad that we are finally dealing with this, because we owe it to Jozef Chovanca and his family. According to some NGOs, cases of police brutality are most often dismissed under the carpet. In the Member States, we need to introduce an independent police inspection, collect detailed data and thus create a safe environment for the citizens of the European Union.

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we talk about European values, but this is Europe. Spain – asked to investigate and sanction the abusive use of force by police against Catalan protesters, instead they decorate them for their magnificent work. France – where the police are supposed to protect and serve, kill and maim citizens with golf-ball-sized rubber bullets.  Bulgaria – where police systematically target and harass the Roma population and stand—by while neo-Nazis target them and the LGBT community; facilitating ever increasing homophobic assaults, resulting in incidents like in the city of Plovdiv, where 30 to 40 neo-Nazis in open daylight publicly organised a purge of the park. And then graffiti against the organisers who tried to protest. No public outcry, no investigation. No sanction by the police. And Croatia last week, where the police were involved in one of the most staggering episodes of violent torture committed against refugees and migrants. Stripped, beaten, robbed of their money. Their belongings burned. Children raped with the branch of a tree. (The speaker holds up a banner) Is this the European values committed by our police. It is an outrage!

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Colleague Daly, I am compelled to state that according to our Rules of Procedure banners are not allowed, but thank you for your speech.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Madam President, on police cars across Europe, we can read the inscriptions 'help and protect', 'help and protect'. This is all the more shocking when people's lives are being lost in the hands of the police for no reason.  This is also the case for the Slovak citizen, Jozef Chovaovec, who in February 2018 did not even get help or protection. Instead, Belgian police officers kneel at him for 16 minutes and made fun of his ordeal. It is incomprehensible that we only learned of this scandal more than two years after this tragic event.  Immediately after the shocking information about the manifestations of brutality and extremism was made public, we took action. And it's good news that the Belgian police, as well. It has set up teams to investigate the incident and witnesses have also begun to be questioned at my instigation. In this context, I would also like to pay tribute to the current accommodating attitude of Mr De Mesmaeker, Commissioner-General of the Belgian Federal Police. But it was only from the highest places that the pressure had to come in for something to happen that should be taken for granted. In this case, therefore, we need to know the answers to the questions: Why did this happen? Why did we find out about this so late? And when will justice be inferd and brought? I appreciate the work of all honest police officers, but I want to stress that human life and human health are paramount. Only then do various treatments come in.  So I believe that this case will also be solved and the culprits will be punished.  I believe that our appeal will also lead to police procedures being changed by fulfilling the essence of a police officer's mission and thus helping and protecting. And I believe it will never happen again so that cases of police brutality are not objectively investigated. Police brutality and extremism cannot have a place in our Union. May today be dedicated to the memory of Mr. Jozef Chovatec.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, the reason for this debate is the death of The Slovak Jozef Chovanec. We've already told you about it. As a Belgian representative, I am deeply affected, like almost all my compatriots, by what happened in the Belgian cell. I hope for the bereaved families, but also for the rule of law in my country, that there will be clarity and transparency about what has happened, and with the right legal follow-up. Ladies and gentlemen, our police and security services in Europe are crucial in our society. That is why it is so important - and the Commissioner has referred to it many times - that there is confidence in these services. Let us be clear, this debate is not about protecting the vast majority of our police forces, the men and women who do what they are trained to do every day, especially society and its inhabitants. But we should not be blind to the fact that the figures in our police departments on, for example, racial profiling or arbitrary arrests, including racial arrests, are increasing. We don't really have a good view of those figures and that's a real problem. We need to know what's going on in our services. Transparency is important and we must not turn a blind eye to the extremism that is present in our police forces. I regret that we cannot pay enough attention to this in this debate today. Here too, transparency and clarity are needed and it will be essential to strengthen our services in our society on the basis of trust.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Madam President, (inaudible) have seen the shocking recording of police brutality against Jozef Chovanec, a Slovak citizen, perpetrated by members of the Belgian police in Charleroi, which led to his death. Of course it goes without saying that the behaviour of those police officers is deeply troubling, especially against the background of protests in the US against the killing of George Floyd. It need not be said that excessive, inappropriate use of force contravenes the European Convention on Human Rights, as well as the Belgian Constitution.  Now there was public outrage in Slovakia and Belgium and across Europe, and rightfully so, not least because the proper investigation only picked up steam after public pressure and after the video was released. And again, it goes without saying that there can be no discrimination when it comes to the treatment of EU citizens by the various police forces across Member States. This is why I believe that the issue deserves a broader inquiry. I believe that Europol should look into the actions of police officers and police training across the EU to make sure that EU citizens receive equal treatment. They must feel safe to go anywhere in the European Union without fear of being discriminated against and their rights disrespected by local police forces. We will continue to press on and follow the case of Jozef Chovanec and push for justice for him and his family, but it cannot stop there.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate is on police brutality in Europe, but since I have been in Parliament I have never listened to the opposite debate, namely the attacks on the police.  In Italy, every three hours, a police officer is attacked, which means eight assaults a day, which means 235 assaults a month. Last year, more than 6 000 officers ended up in hospital for receiving assaults, often by immigrants, and this is on the increase. Yet then at some point we come here to Europe and even they are accused of brutality.  Like any category, of course, there is someone who is wrong, so much so that they, think about it, ask for cameras on their uniforms. Let us say that the left tends to symbolize with criminals, instead of defending those who defend us every day. My group and I are always on the side of the police and we also thank them.

name: Alviina ALAMETSÄ
text: – Madam President, we have been devastated to witness police brutality in the US, Hong Kong and Belarus. However, the same violent acts, even people dying in police custody, happen inside our own borders, especially to ethnic minorities.  My home country, Finland, has one of the most trusted police forces, yet we just saw the police using pepper spray against non-violent climate protesters. Some of the protesters were children. To me, this is painful news because I started my political activism in the street as a climate activist. How can you trust the police after this kind of incident?  We need to take action. If the police is tasked to regulate itself, as it often is, there is a conflict of interest. Police forces needs training, regulation, oversight and accountability. Police should be here to make us all feel safe, not afraid.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Before taking up my mandate in the European Parliament, I had the honour of overseeing the Polish police as Minister of the Interior in the Government of the Republic of Poland. This period is a source of pride for me to be able to see the professionalism, dedication and dedication of police officers on a daily basis, who, often at the risk of life, have taken care of the safety of citizens. I was also able to see personally, through the cooperation of the Polish police with our partners in the European Union, that this professionalism and dedication to the fight against the most dangerous crime, such as terrorism, trafficking in human beings, weapons, drugs and paedophilia, also accompanies police officers throughout the European Union on a daily basis. Today, however, we are discussing the pathological and unacceptable attitude and criminal behaviour of police officers. This is undeniably appalling and condemnable behaviour, but it must not authorise the generalisation and unfair assessment of the thousands of hard-working and security-caring police officers. Sometimes – let us remember – they pay the highest price, the price of their own life.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, in August this year, the general public, not only in Slovakia, Belgium, but throughout the Union, became aware with dismay of the background to the tragic case that cost the life of the Slovak father of jozef Chovaovec's family more than two and a half years ago.  This happened after a brutal raid by Belgian police at Charleroi airport. The whole case is all the more doomed because, in addition to the excessive use of force by the police, there has also been a clear manifestation of right-wing extremism. It is incomprehensible to me that, until recently, on the part of the Belgian competent authorities, there was not enough will to properly investigate the case and punish those responsible, and the whole approach changed positively only after the media published the video, recorded by the security cameras, and the brutal crackdown on a citizen of an EU Member State proved completely incomprehensible and unacceptable to us.  We, and I personally, have tried in our practice to include this item on the agenda for today's debate, but I have not succeeded in adopting a resolution, which unfortunately failed, but it is good that today's debate will also raise awareness not only of this case affecting the Slovak citizen, but also of the necessity of all Member States, not only new or older, so Belgium. , as well as Slovakia, to take concrete steps to combat the manifestations of extremism, violence and racism in the police forces. Such manifestations have no place in our society, let alone in the state branches, which are normally responsible for upholding the rule of law.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Madam President, four days ago, Samuel Paty, a history teacher, was beheaded in France in the middle of the day by an Islamist terrorist, fortunately very quickly brought under control by the police - whose work I salute with dedication despite a climate of great violence against the police officers. Four days after this barbaric act, we are proposed here to discuss a subject essentially exaggerated and agitated, at least in France, by the Islamo-leftists: that of police violence. While another civilization organized around political Islam has settled on our European continent and threatens France with its separatism, Parliament, disconnected from reality, remains in denial and sees more violence elsewhere. In France, in 8 years, there have been 263 victims of the violence of political Islam and not of police violence: it is this fight against terrorism and not police violence that we should debate, and the figures attest to this. Ms Johansson, fighting terrorism without stopping immigration is a sham. This issue of civilization must now fully and fully occupy our work because, I tell you, tomorrow it will be too late.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Let us remember that most police officers do a very good job for all citizens of the European Union, but of course there are abuses. And most importantly, and the biggest problem is when these abuses are authorized by the state, and their scale. There are only a few countries in the European Union that are at the forefront of this statement, and this is a real violation of the rule of law. One such country, of course, is France. Let us pay attention to the statistics: the police last year, in 2019, killed 26 people, including 11 people in the yellow vest protests alone. Five people have lost their hands since the grenade exploded, 2,000 injured. The media is talking about almost 95 attacks on journalists. I therefore have a question, when will there be a debate on the violation of the rule of law in France, and what is President Macron doing? Are they equal and equal in this House?  I would also like to hear what the situation is like in Germany as well. We have all seen what has happened in Dusseldorf, and we have also seen what happened in Rhineland-Westphalia when, environmentalists – and women – brutally pulled the police from the trees. That is why I would like to hear what this situation is like. And about Belgium, it should be a separate debate at all, about this situation in Belgium.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Madam President, good policing is a consequence of understanding the moral responsibility that comes with holding power. The legitimacy of policing is based upon consent, integrity and accountability. 2020 has brought an appetite for change and self—examination. We should not miss this opportunity to renew our social contract and better ourselves as a society, not only to ensure we stamp out any abuses of power or acts of brutality within our police forces, but also to bring to an end the growing threat of violence to police officers on our streets. These are difficult discussions to have but they are necessary. When our institutions and those within it fail, which at times they do, we must not hesitate to hold our own feet to the fire. Acknowledging the wrongdoing of the few does not undermine the integrity of the many, it only strengthens it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, last year after Floyd's death, there were demonstrations in this chamber, there were declarations on the part of the Black Panthers, of Antifa, of all anarchists, of all communists. Two years before that, however, Hohenetz died, and not a word about it. A teacher was beheaded in France the other day. There are no declarations, no fists raised, no anxious appeals.  Why, honorable? It is very simple: because both victims were Europeans, they were Christians, they were part of this civilization; and their murderers were persecuted and defended by whom, by anti-fascists, by Antifa, by the Black Panthers, and by all other Marxist, extremist far-left organizations that waged a cultural war against our civilization, against our roots, and against our belief in Christianity. That's the reason, that's the double standard. Otherwise, we fight in Poland, we argue to Hungary that there were no rights there and no rule of law. In conclusion, I express my sympathy with the Bulgarian police, who for 100 days, despite their pitiful equipment, their pitiful remuneration, managed to resist the provocations of anti-fascists, communists, provocateurs who throw bombs, stones, trees and whatever they fall.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Madam President, on 1 October 2017, Spanish police brutally beat thousands of Catalan citizens who were only trying to vote peacefully. Images of people in blood have gone around the world, you've seen them all. At the time, I was responsible for health in the Catalan government. My department's report reported more than 1,000 physical and psychological injuries. What has the Union done on this issue? What did the Commission say? Nothing. Silence. An embarrassing, shameful silence! We criticise police abuses everywhere, in Belarus, turkey, even in Belgium, but when Spain abuses it, it is an internal matter. In the name of the unity of Spain, is everything allowed? While the Strasbourg Court condemned Spain for not being proportionate, Spain was honouring the police officers who beat Catalans. Perhaps the duty of proportionality is not valid in the case of the Catalan national minority? Europe, stop being silent in the face of this repression!

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this debate and I very much welcome the strong commitment from the European Parliament to act on these issues.  Many of you have referred to the tragic loss of Mr Chovanec’s life and we all share the emotions when we saw these shocking images, and I will also – as many of you already done – convey my deepest sympathy to Mr Chovanec’s family.  It’s of utmost importance that the Belgian authorities carry out independent and accountable investigations. We need to know all the facts, identify those responsible and take appropriate legal actions.  I have the utmost trust respect and admiration for all the brave police women and policemen who do their duty, day in, day out to protect us. They are doing a great job. They have a very tough job and they deserve our support. But sadly the tragedy of Mr Chovanec is not the only one. That’s why we have to end racism. No institution is immune. Not the Commission, not the Parliament, not the police. Fighting racists will improve their ability to enforce the law, because law enforcement builds on the trust of the community.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Honourable Members, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work I saw today's debate here in the European Parliament as encouragement and also as an encouragement in our commitment to our values, to the rule of law, to democracy, to human rights. In this respect, I too would like to thank you warmly, on behalf of the Council, for this important impetus and for this contribution. And so that there is no doubt at all, precisely because many Members have pointed out the tragic case of Jozef Chovanec: we too – the German Presidency – deeply regret the death of Mr Chovanec. Such a debate as we have had today is always painful. It is painful for those affected. Above all, it is also painful for the state and its political representatives, because the security authorities, in a society in which the state has a monopoly on violence, also have a special responsibility, of course, for us to act decisively, resolutely against any inappropriate behaviour by the police and in our security authorities. Resolute action against racism, decisive action against homophobia, decisive action against anti-Gypsyism and nationalism.  And when we do that, we are protective of the many, many police officers who do an excellent job every day. They protect us as citizens, they protect our liberal democracies, they protect our rule of law, they protect what is important to us, what is valuable to us and what essentially makes us Europeans.  And because – as I pointed out in my introductory remarks – the Member States are also responsible under our Treaties, it naturally also creates a duty for all Member States to shoulder this responsibility and for all cases to be investigated in accordance with the procedures of the rule of law. And these investigations within the framework of the rule of law also serve to protect the many police officers who protect us and our democratic societies.  Thank you again for this debate, and I hope that something will come of it, namely a clear commitment to the rule of law for all of us.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Police officers often take care of our safety at risk of life, often in difficult circumstances. Of course, like everyone else, they make mistakes, and there are abuses. Sometimes these abuses are legied by state authorities. Sometimes the police become an instrument in the hands of the authorities to serve to restrict freedoms and civil liberties. Such cases happen in many European countries, but they are surprisingly not accused of violating the rule of law. And yet it is then that we have a serious problem with it. In France, for example, 26 people were killed, including 11 during the yellow vest protests, and 2,000 injured as a result of police abuse. In addition, according to media reports, there have been 95 attacks by the French police on journalists. Recently, the European Court of Human Rights sentenced Spain in a trial for abuse of force by police officers who beat up participants in a legal protest. A tragic event has also occurred here in Belgium. Two years ago, Slovak national Józef Chovanec was detained at Charleroi Airport and fatally beaten by five police officers. One of the officers made a Nazi gesture and pretended to be Hitler. So far, no investigation has been carried out into this scandalous case. I therefore ask whether we will see a debate in the EP on violations of the rule of law in these countries?

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On 7 August 2005, the European public witnessed the actions of the Polish Police, which raise great doubts as to respect for human rights and the proportionality of the measures used. As we have seen, a spontaneous gathering of activists and activists defending another activist, Margot, was broken up against the controversial arrest. As indicated by the participating respondents, as well as the Ombudsman and Polish parliamentarians, the actions of the Police and the way in which they are conducted raise doubts. In their opinion, the Police used inadequate coercive measures, both against those participating in the meeting and against bystanders, sometimes randomly detained, and the detainees did not subsequently have guaranteed the right of contact with a lawyer. The media also reported on the lack of safe conditions for detainees and possible sexual harassment of detainees at the command. Is the Police's action against LGBT+ people in 2020 the result of a hate policy pursued by the Law and Justice government and other right-wing parties that feel unpunished in the face of the indifference of the EU institutions, or already a systemic problem? Can citizens and citizens, especially the LGBT+ community, feel safe in their own country? Are these all standards in line with EU values? How long does it take for the EC to stop turning a blind eye and evading responsibility for tackling police brutality?
